element_texts.text:
Mrs. P. A. Reardon
At Sea

Dear Ma, 
We left New York 30th May 1884.   the first few days out rather rough and unpleasant. The Constitution still keeps her name up as a fast sailer.  Made the passage from New York to Fayal. In 17 days.   Fayal is one of the most Western of the Western isles it resembles in appearance at a distance an immense crocadile laying out at full length It is a beautiful island well cultivated.  . The western isle are all of them composed of lava the soil on some is very fine being decomposed lava and Pumice it has one peculiar advantage over other soils viz. that it improves with age.

Flores is the farthest west of the Azores it is a very rugged island and has but few inhabitants. There are great many  hot springs in the above mentioned island.  Many of them emitting sulphurous fumes.  the highest point of Flores is about 1200 feet. We passed within about 6 miles of it Orta is the principal town in the island of Fayal and in also the capital of the island.  it contains




May 1844
Buckner (at sea) to his mother,
-on a voyage from New York to Fayal
-gives descriptions of the land Fayal

about 8000 inhabitants.  There is no harbour in the island only an open roadstead off Orta.  Orta is a beautiful place at a short distance but like most of Portugese towns when you get into them you find the streets narrow and dirty without side walks.  the houses look clean on the outside because the are White Washed.  but most of them are more like [crossed  out: a] hog pens inside that any thing else.  The American Consul was very kind to us during our stay.  asked all the officers to make his house their home during our stay.  he has beautiful gardens fine farms and is the Most Wealthy Man in the island.  the hills back of Orta present a beautiful view  They are laid off so very regular with hedges between and in some places a row of small trees.   There is a large quantity of corn & wheat raised in this island and some 4 or 5 years since  plenty of orange trees grew in the island, but they have all been destroyed by a small insect about the size of a Flax seed, 9 miles from the city is the choldero or principal crater of the island.




He tells his mother that Orta is a beautiful place and describes it 
He talks about how the American Council is friendly and how they welcomed them to their town. He says an officer took him into his home and he says the man is wealthy and talks about his garden.

it is about 1200 feet deep 5 -miles in circumference and has a small lake at the bottom is a beautiful as well as a grand sight. there is a small village at the bottom near the lake, and numerous flocks of goats and sheep grazing near and around it. besides which there are numerous vineyards around the brink of the crater just among the  clouds, about 8 miles from Fayal is the island of Pico it is a single peak it is nearly 8,000 feet high the clouds make a continued belt around it about half way up to the peak. The Peak of Pico is an extinct crater yet steam still issues from it and during the winter months when all the high hills are covered with snow the Peak is bare on account of the hot vapours issuing from it. There is a kind of vine raised in Pico very similar to Madeira it takes a good judge to tell the difference. There is about 20,000 pipes produced every year Pico & Fayal together contain about 30,000 inhabitants These islands are under the Portuguese flag.   the evening before we sailed the America  [corner torn away]




Talks more about Orta 
- says its a beautiful grand sight
-gives detailed description of the lake, villages, flocks of goats and sheep
Pico is 8 miles from Fayal. He also gives detailed description of Pico. Says winter is covered with snow

Consul gave the officers a party his house it was a very pleasant affair. There was many ladies there who spoke english and several of them Americans of course we enjoyed ourselves for a mid enjoys himself any where,  The next morning I sent the mess boy on shore to buy a few stores for the mess.  The black rascal got drunk spent 10$ and brought off a dozen eggs and one dozen bottles of wine. All hands were called up anchor in the Evening about 5 got underway. And put out to sea, on the 22 June. Being caterer of the mess having a dozen of wine under my change and a dozen of eggs. and having also a pleasant set of watch mates and a long lonesome mid watch to keep the moon being below the horizon so that it was dark at pitch on deck.  All things favouring I slipped below made six glasses of egg-nog for three of us and brought it on deck. then with the assistance of a piece of Cake which one of the mids had sent to him in  [torn corner of page]  we passed of the mid watch

handsomely it was a merry watch until old [torn page corner] hickuped fell down and went to sleep then another one hickup tried to walk the deck but always brought up against the bulwarks. At 4 AM one was left able to call the watch which he did.  And was found asleep next morning under the stern of the launch, the next mid watch passed off the same way with the exception of keeping their heads a little clearer.  The next first watch two mids came up to take a lunar the poor fellows joined us and took a bottle of wine in the place of the moon.   our next watch there was only two more bottles left.  Now the Name for an empty bottle amongst mids is a dead soldier and a full one a marine on guard.  Well about [crossed out: 1 oclock]  two oclock one of my watch mates came to me and asked me with a long face if I would not lend him a hand to kill a Marine and heave him over-board, this awful as well as horrible plan we revealed to our other watch mate, who joined us heart and soul in the proposed murder, with due precaution [stain in lower right corner of page]

[stain on page] brought the poor innocent unoffending Marine on deck stuck a cork screw in his neck bled him to death and fineally hove him overboard.  this single murder did not satisfy our watch, they determined to be guilty of a double murder, the seized on the only remain marine.  The Cork screw being lost they broke his neck with a belaying pin bled him to death and hove him overboard, myself and watch-mates had become so noisey that the officer of the deck ordered us to keep silence two or three times, one of the mids wanted to go over on the weather side, and [crossed out: him] flog him (the officer of the deck.)  After our watch was out we went below kicked up such a row turning in our hammocks that all the mids commenced growling, the most amusing part was to see one of us turn in one side of his hammock and fall out the other, and another mid trying to pull his pants off without setting down to it.  first he would lift up one leg and pull which would trip him up.  then up and try it again down [stain on page] [?he?] would set with a bump that would make

the tumblers rattle on the lockers.  After nearly [stain on page] himself with his bumps and falls he came to the sage conclusion, of turning in with them on, and cursing the tailor who made them adding with a hickup but never mind old fellow you a'in't paid for them yet and that a'in't half you a ... fell asleep.  On the 25th we came to in Funchall Roads in the island of Madeira.  Madeira is a rough and rugged island the very productive it is useless to say anything in praise of the wine for it is well known that it is the best in the 
wold [sic].  The Town of Funchal is a beautiful place more of a business place than Fugal.  The place is very strongly fortified and the streets are kept very clean and neat and are paved with a kind of hard gravel wedged together there are no cars or carriages in the island every thing being dragged on a kind of slide.   3 miles from the town in the edge of the clouds is the church of the lady of the Mount  there is an excellant road up to it.   Our watch got liberty a few days after we came in [stain on page obscures end of two lines]  [?] soon as we got ashore we were surrounded by [?] and were almost forced to take one of them upon

June, They were very fine little animals and very hardy we had a very pleasant ride up to the church the road is shaded on each side by large Sycamore trees near the Church is a beautiful garden belonging to the English Consul one of the prettiest on the island, the American Consul is very much of a gentleman he gave us a blow-out which we all enjoyed laid in a lot of stores for our mess at this place sailed on the 29th June for Santa Cruz in 24 hours we were laying at anchor in the above mentioned place. Santa Cruz is the capital of the island of Teneriffe  it is a real piratical hole and is resorted to [o crossed out]  more by slavers than any other craft.  Capt. Percivall ran a pirate down some 4 years ago took him and delivered him over to the Spanish authorities, Santa Cruz is a strongly fortified place it was at this place that Lord Nelson lost his arm. There is a stand of colors in one of the churches that were taken from him at the battle, Santa Cruz contains 10,000 inhabitants and is situated on the SE side of the island. The NE & SE part of the island is remarkably Rough and barren.

From the anchorage off Santa Cruz there can be seen nothing but barren rocks with now and then a few sprigs of the prickle pear starting up amongst them. The day after we got in a party of six were formed for going up to the Peak  We expected to be absent about 3 days got our pea jackets and blankets ready for a tramp amongst the mountains  It appeared so curious to me that we should be getting Pea Jackets and blankets ready for a ride in the month of July in Lat 28◦ N and as hot as blazes, found horses waiting for us at the American consuls. Mounted and started about 5 AM 1st July.  put-off in a hard gallop in order to avoid the numerous beggers who flocked around us in the streets. The road from Santa Cruz to Laguna is very good being well paved, one of the most singular things that first struck me was the camels with their dark skinned drivers I began almost to fancy that we were in the great Sahara Desert amongst some of the wild rocks and mountains that travelers sometimes speak of.  10 miles from Santa Cruz is the City of Laguna the ancient capital of the isle it contains about 10,000 inhabitants it is

a better built place than Santa Cruz it is about 4000 feet above the level of the sea it rains nearly every day in Laguna. Near Laguna can be found mummies of the former inhabitants the were called Guanchas and were all massacred at the conquest of the island which was about 800 years ago, near and around Laguna in an extensive plain one of the most fertile in the world. It produces some of the finest wheat I ever saw. On account of the elevation it rains almost every day so that the crops never suffer for want of moisture, it is a very pleasant ride from Laguna to Matanzas.  In Laguna we stoped at the Posada or Hotel. Tried to get something to eat but could get nothing not a cup of coffee for the love of money or anything else. At Matanzas we stopped broke into our mess stores. Got a lot of ripe figs and a bowl of peaches and milk. Made a first rate dinner and started.  Matanzas is a quiet little place it's name tells its history. The word Matanzas means slaughter it was at this place that the last of the Guanchas were

assembled and slaughtered to a man. But few strangers ever visit  this place and our arrival was [?] of a great deal of curiosity. I do not think the Great Boa Constrictor or camel Leopard in our country would have made a greater stir. At any rate as we rode thro the streets at every window could be seen two or three faces some of them quite pretty   The houses in Teneriffe are usually two stories high built of the hewn lava, and white washed, very few of the houses have any glass in the windows. The climate being warm it can be dispensed with by the poor,  three or 4 miles from Matanzas is the small village of Victoria. having also reference to some of the massacres of the Natives, the country near and around it is beautiful being covered with verdure in every direction. The hedges are all formed of the Hundred year plant. We saw some 50 or 100 in bloom. They are almost as common here as the elm or oak trees in America. Near Victoria we met with a man who was to guide us to the consuls. From Victoria to Orotava the road is rather rough but leads directly across the valley of [?Tocohonti?] one

one of the richest and healthiest in the world.  it has several very pretty towns on the sea coast whilst it extends back and up to the clouds every spot appears to be in a high state of cultivation the  bottoms of the deep chasm the rough and wild looking ravines and the steep sides of the almost perpendicular cliffs all appear to yield something, tho it was in this beautiful valley that we saw a group of the most wretched beings that I had ever met with before. They appeared to be one family all linked together by one strong band and that was misery.  They were living in a loathsome cave the large spiders  creeping over the cold ashes (for they had not wood enough to keep a fire) and now and then a lizard would jump from one rock to another as if he with the rest of the world cared not for them. The Mother appeared to be a woman about 30 years of age. She wore an old dirty ragged gown that looked as if it might have seen 20 of them.  her children wore nothing. I surveyed the place but could see nothing to eat and apparently no place to keep any thing. The little children begged us

with out stretched arms for something, some of our party chopped them something and we cleared out glad to get rid of such sights and thankful to god that our country had not come to such a pass as this. about 1/4 of a mile further on we passed another cave. a perfect likeness of the former, we arrived in Orotava about 4 PM, dined with the consul who is a very fine old man (A M [?Cullen?]) treated us to some good old English Porter &c. In the morning we started after an early breakfast for the Peak of Teneriffe.  Stopped at the Botanical gardens which are beautifully laid out with many fountains and large pools with beautiful red fish are scattered tho the garden in all directions. Here we found plants from America Europe Asia and Africa besides many beautiful flowers natives of the island, after satisfying ourselves with the garden we again mounted and in about 1 hour was in the City of Orotava which is about 2 miles from the Port of the same name. here we called on the Marchoness of ------ and daughters very agreeable women they amused us by a little playing and singing on the Piano and treated us to a glass of wine. In her garden is a tree

Known as the dragon tree from it fancied resemblance to the Hydra it is 50 feet in circumference and was a full grown tree at the time of the Conquest which was about 100 years ago. There are many hieroglyphics cut on its trunk which are said to have been done by the ancient inhabitants. After touring Orotava the 2, the hills being to get very steep and we had to ascend by a zig zag path as it was impossible to go straight up. when near a field of labourers every mothers son and daughters of them would, run for us as hard as the devil would let them begging us for money. This we found the case as far up as the clouds where cultivation ceases, when just underneath the clouds the rough hills back of Orotavo tho almost mountains in themselves sunk into mere mound such was the difference between them and the one which we were on. It was at this place that we found our ascent becoming more and more difficult vegitation had become more and more scant. the vine had long since disappeared  the oat fields next succeeded but they with the

wheat and other fields of the temperate clime were fast disappearing and when we finally entered the thick mists of the mountain these disappeared and a thick green growth of some kind of bushes much like the Holly succeeded. and when thro the clouds vegetation ceases almost entirely.  in truth if I should except a beautiful shrub growing to the highth of 20 feet with pink blossoms there would be none at-all, when a few hundred feet above the clouds we stoped (to blow our horses and take a look at the surrounding scenery. As well as to get a few Mouth-fulls to eat and drink.)   Near a large heap of rocks some 50 or 60 feet high which heap had one day or other been one solid rock. and had been thrown from the crater of El-Veyo mount which was then 6 or 8 miles to the N' of us.  and with an immense chasm extending down down to an unknown depth for 600 feet below as the clouds and mists were rolling and boiling like some immense pot and intercepted our vision tho far above us the on the points of the rocks sat two or three bald eagles every now and then streaming forth

in their wild notes rendered still more so by the wild hoken? scenery around us. Under the shade of these rocks with a few dead limbs of the only kind of shrub or bush or tree that grows up there we raised a fire unpacked our horses. Cooked and eat until we were satisfied. talked of our friends and of home spliced the Main Brace Mounted our horses and rode on, From this place we had a fine view of the peak. as we also did of the clouds beneath us, we were about 5000 feet above the sea and also above the clouds yet the Peak was twice as high above us as we were above the sea, the sky above us was as clear as it could be not a speck to be seen and the clouds below us as white as snow and rolling up against the sides of the mountain like an ocean of foam. the clouds from above make very much the same appearance as the sea does from a ship or other object it does not appear to be convers on top as it appears to be be concave from below but spreads out like an immense plain and the sky

forms a horizon with the clouds very similar to the horizon of the clouds with the sea, one of our company who was some what of a humorist and was very fond of a good glass of grog remarked that the clouds looked like an immense dish of egg-nog, we ascended some 4 or 5 hundred feet from our dinner place some times loosing sight of the peak and again seeing its cone towering above every other object. Our path was as rough as it well could be never admitting two abreast and some times tight squeezing for one this part of our ascent was not only difficult but annoying on account of the slowness of our go ahead as we always had to go 30 yards to get 10 when about the above height viz of 400 feet, above the resting place. we came to an extensive plain of Pumice stone almost as barren as the desert of Sahara only ever 1/4 of a mile or so one of those beautiful shrubs with pink blossoms. This plain was some 10 or 15 miles in length and gradually ascends to the foot of the peak. It is covered with immense stones some of them solid and almost

round then other split into thousands of fragments. These appear to have been thrown from the Peak during some irruption. Some of these stones were at least 100 feet in diameter and were so hard that I could strike fire with a piece the same as from a flint. thro this Pumice we found it rather hard riding as our horses sank up to their knees at every step and tho cold and uncomfortable in the shade the sun beat down on our heads so that we felt our faces fairly burn again. After ascending the whole extent of this plane we agin commenced a steep and difficult ascent going in a zig zag path steping three feet ahead and sliping two back. Until we got to a place known as the English resting place. The English resting place is a flat spot about 7 miles from the Peak and is protected from the wind by three or four large rocks that have fallen near together as it was quite cold up here and we all were pretty hungry we sent our guides out to collect us wood from the shrubs that were growing around built a fire cooked

a good supper spread our blankets and being rather tired was soon in a sound sleep. about 10 oclock some of the most wakeful of our party roused up all of us opened two or three bottles of wine and as we had to start for the Peak in an hour or so we ate a hearty supper drank to our own good healths and also to the friends we left behind us. We all found the mountain air very dry (our guides informed us it never rains up at that high and  but seldom snows) besides which the least moisture evaporates very quickly on account of the rarity of the atmosphere, and we had constantly to keep wetting our mouths, by 12 we had all come to the conclusion that it was best to make a move. So each of us putting some-thing to eat in our pockets, we recommenced our journey for about one mile the pumice was very light and soft and very difficult to walk up after the Pumice came about 3 miles of rough stone all loose tho much better walking than the pumice after picking our

way over these rocks as well as we could some times climbing on all fours and at others feeling our way with our staffs for the stones being loose a false step might start some of them to rolling and then it would be a gone case with him or as the sailors say it would be a clew up and a furl with him   The ascent now became so difficult the air so rare that we had to stop every 2 or 300 yards to get breath as the thin air would not satisfy our  our respiration. Several of our company became sick and threw up. All of us were affected with a curious dizziness. So much so that some of the huge hills and rocks arounds us would fairly dance a jig. and once when laying on my back and puffing and blowing like a porpoise, I called the attention of the company to what I though was a metor or shooting star which turned out to be nothing else than one of the fixed stars, then again all the blood in our bodies appeared to rush to our heads

it was during one of our resting spells that
some one or two of our company proposed
turning back declairing that it was a piece
of foolishnes and it was no use to go any
farther but they could not prevail on the
rest and of course we went ahead.
when ascending the cone. we had to stop
some half dozen times as it was very
tiresome during our stopages. we all
would look out for some soft rock
with another rock to keep the wind off
these rocks we always found warm and 
in two or three instances I enjoyed a
good nap. about 20 minutes before
day light we were at the mouth of the
crater. it was during some of our
resting spells that I first noticed the
extreme clearness of the air the fixed
stars of the 2' and 3' magnitude appearing
nearly as bright as as Venus or Jupiter
we found it as we expected very cold on
the summit but as the rocks were all
warm and those in the crater hot we

had but little difficulty in keeping warm
when day light first appeared we could
still see that the country below us was
veiled in thick darkness and even when
the sun rose in all its brghtness brighter
than I had ever seen it before. for the air
was clearer we could see that
that it was sill [sic] night. that twilight had not
as yet began to show its self, around the base of the 
mountain, when we had fairly rested our-selves
and had taken a mouthful to eat. some one
of the company proposed giving three cheers to the
day (the 4th of July) and also splicing the main
[?hace?] this was accordingly done. After which M.W
commenced repeating the declaration of Independence
he had got about half tho when he interrupted 
himself by pointing to the W and saying look there
and truely it was a sight worth seeing. for 
the sun had just risen two or three degrees above
the eastern horizon of white clouds and far in the 
west could be seen a shadow of the peak the
exact shape of the mountain in fact it was a

shadow on a shadow for the dark shadow of the
Earth could be seen on the Western sky. Near the 
Horizon almost black a little higher of a deep brown
then a red then orange and a light pink.
the shadow of the Peak was a deep blue [crossed out: of] for it
was a shadow on a shadow as the day grew brighter
we could see the sea shore and also the 7 other island
of the group the farthest off being about 140 miles
we could not see the base of any of them but only the
tops as the rest of the islands were below the clouds
the crater is about 2 or 300 feet deep the sides and 
bottom of it is coated with sulphur alum and
a great many other mineral substances. Teneriffe
is said to be an extinct volcano (as there has not been
any eruption for about 50 years. during it - the
town of Ecore was partially destroyed and the harbor
filled up with the lava. The lava can now be seen
in and around the peak apparently as fresh as 
if had been done yesterday)   yet the crater is so 
hot inside that it burnt our feet and shoes and
at the bottom there is such a bubbling and hissing
that is is difficult to hear.   After getting as many
curiosities as our pockets would hold we requested

our guide to show in the way down which he
did, our guide was a native of the island
and from what we saw of him we (at least I)
was under the impression that he would never
tire, for he had already the day before
walked from the city of Orotava and led a 
horse all the way and never complained but
was always encouraging us to go ahead. About
two miles from the English Resting place is a 
natural well it always has water or rather ice
in it. it is about 30 feet deep and more like
a cave than a well, there is also a great many
places on the side of the mountain above this well
whence sulphur and steam issues from. at 10 AM
we ate our breakfasts at the English Resting place
and commenced the descent which we accomplished
without accident and the only thing of interest was
a fight between two of the guides wich ended 
with a bloody nose and a black Eye. When we 
got to Orotava without ceremony we laid down 
here and there some on couches some on chairs
and M.W on a bed I was asleep in about two

minutes and grumbled when They woke me up
for dinner at 5 PM. as soon as I got my dinner
I went to bed again and did not wake up till
6 oclock next morning. In Orotava there was building
a small vessel of 80 or 100 tons   she was built of 
the Teneriffe Pine which is very similar to the
pitch pine of America. From the best accounts I
could get I am led to believe that the Gulf Stream
sweeps tho these islands and as far to the Eastward
as Cape Blanco in Africa.  as vessels that are wrecked
on the coast of America and particularly on the New
Foundland banks are frequently picked up amongst these
islands and there is lot of half pirates who make
a business of going to the Cape to pick up the
wrecks which they sell for lumber. Two months before
we came in to Santa Cruz a large ship drifted into 
the Grand Canary keel up nothing alive on board her 
cargo was very valuable.   After breakfast we started
for the ship (after biding good-bye to M' Cullum who was 
a very kind and gentlemanly man) when on the high
land between Orotava and Santa Cruz we got a good
wetting from a heavy shower besides our horses in
two or three instances slipped down tho luckily

without hurting any one of of us. My horse slipped down
twice once within 5 feet of a precipice 50 or 60 feet high
The bridles that are used on the horses appear to me
to be very cruel They have no bitts but have a stout
iron band across the nose and two long irons extending
under his chin to which the reins are made fast. Then
a chain goes round under the chin and if you should
pull hard you will either break his nose or capsize
him  Some of the Horses had lumps on their Noses half
an inch high.  The dress of some of the peasants of
the island is very pretty.   one dress in particular I
noticed was a short mantle or a cloak with a scarlet
vest   Pants open at the side thro which they show a 
pair of white drawers.   the drawers extend below the pants
some three or 4 inches then a pair white goat skin boots
with fancy tops and a large straw hat completes the suit
We met a lot of women between Laguna & Santa Cruz
one of them had 40 large five gallon Earthen pots on 
her head the rest of them with about 30 or 35.  In the
chain gang which was at work on the Road we were
hailed by a fellow who called himself an American
and told us he had been 3 years in the gang
and the cause of it was being taken in a slaver

we dined with the American consul in Santa Cruz. Santa Cruz is a very strong place it was here that Lord Nelson was beaten off with the loss of an arm,  The forts are now in want of repairs.  The place can be approached to within pistol shot by a line of battle ship.  The [crossed out:  town]  situation for the town is badly chosen  there is no landing place with an Easterly wind besides there is no water to be had without an immense deal of trouble.  There is Much better places both to the N' & S' of it.  There is a kind of horse maceral caught here with hook and line.  of a night they raise a fire in their boats (this is a good mark to anchor by should a vessel come in during the night.)  they do not fish in the day time but always by fire light as the fire attracts the fish.  The language is not the pure Spanish but has many Moorish words in it.  We found at St. Cruz a French Jack [?] Frigate.  She had an ugly Hull but was neat looking enough aloft,  the usual salutes were exchanged between us and the Frenchman.  We learned she was bound to Rio and would sail the same Evening we hove short and when she sheeted home her topsails we

hove  up our anchor braced the yards as the occasion
required set top gallant sails jib and spanker
the Frenchman was soon after us about 2 miles astern
at sundown we could see his topsails above water
when it fell almost calm. the next morning she
was just within sight astern but we were becalmed
this was Sunday our First Lieut (a good old-gent
and a real Christian & a man who was loved by
all the officers and men but a great old humbug read us a few chapters in 
the Bible and also read over the Episcopal service
When the Boatswain piped to Dinner at 12 M
the Frenchman was within 4 or 5 miles of us having got
a breeze when we caught it. we  kept varying our distance
for two or three days. when we parted company, she
passed in between the Cape De Verge isles and the coast
of Africa whilst we passed  to the W' with our sea watches
returned our old humors of joking &c.  one of our watch
mates who had a very fertile imagination, seated on a Gun 
slide called to me said the Buck old fell spose that hell
was a big ship what a curious old craft she would be
there would be old Nick himself for a capt. Judas
first Luff and old Mahomet Capt of the Main top

and various other hellgum___ for petty officers and an innumerable host of common fellows for sailors, then said he what a high old cargo they would have their spirit room. chock a (rock) with hot lead and the main hold full of (Sulphur) and coal. and should a gale come on you ( in feeling top sails) would hear old nick sing out to mahomet. haul out your well to windward. you (psalin) (singing) thief. then to see old (mike)take a round turn around the mizza (nigging) with-his tail to keep him from falling overboard in a sea-way, and how he would fool some of the fellows when he'd ark them to step below and take some hot (stuff) or a little punch when he would hand them out a glah of hot lead. and should they refuse. would give him a little (punch) in the guts with a hot iron, many a good laugh have (i) had at some of his odd (ideas) july 20th, (giving) the mid watch say a beautiful rain bow. 21st spoke an English, (east) India man bound home, sent them a lot of fresh (grub) an they had been to sea some two or three months, the weather since

leaving the coast of the United States has been
charming never saw such weather before. Some
times we would have a squall of rain but it
would never last longer than two or three hours.
When it would rain drops as large as musket-ball
July 23'd  being close to the line and about two
hundred of our crew having never crossed  it - as
a matter of course we all expected old Father 
Neptune to visit us. Especially as Mr. Wise and 
family were on board and wished to see his 
Oceanic Majesty.  Soon after night fall we 
heard a hoarse voice hailing the ship and 
directly afterwards a man in a strange attire 
looking something like a half fish came aft.
with a document for the capt. Mr. Wise and 
family were on deck and their little daughter 
ran below crying out (frightened) oh mercy [?Nipteins?]
is on board. The Capt after treated the [?]
to a glass of wine which he the sea monster
smacked his lips at and appeared to enjoy as 
much as any human could. The Capt then

told him that he should be very happy to

see.   Father Neptune the powerful god of the seas
That they had once been old Friends and he hoped
he would not forget him.  with this the messenger
departed and soon was seen a blaze of fire
on our starb'  quarter which the tars said was
his boat. (The Neptune company had been
preparing themselves for 8 or 10 days. and all that
was now wanting was a place for a barber 
shop. The armourers and carpenters had constructed
some 8 or 10 razors that would fairly make a 
New York Dandy faint.)  In the morning watch
our boom cover was swung in the lee  gangway.
A Throne was erected just forward of the fore
rigging for Neptune. The Engine being rigged the
boom cover was filled with water. A bench for
the barbers &c &c.  At 9 The band struck up a grand
march and Neptune with his guards, came aft.
Neptune himself on a carriage pulled by six
black Negroes.   These Negroes were bare down to 
the waiste and had Red scales &c painted on them
Then came the guards each with long flowing
robes. and with long white hair an beard

as old apparantly as if it had been growing thousand
of years. Then neptune with his trident and with 
a crown on looking more like a devil than a god
(the guards were each armed with a harpoon) 
then came the barbers each with their shaving 
brush as stiff as coir could be and with their
Razors.  After Neptune has shaken hands with 
the Capt  and bowed to the ladies he was 
treated with a glass of grog by the Capt. and 
also at the same time he the Capt ordered that 
Neptune should have command for the day. 
then commenced the sport.   The first one taken was
the  carpenter a fellow that was not liked by 
the men they placed him up on the bench
scraped nearly all the skin off of his face and
upset him backwards in the  water where he was 
met by three big Negroes who ducked him 
and held him so that the engine would 
play full in his face.  The poor fellow was near 
drowned when he was let loose. Next came the
lieut of Marines he was a fat man about 200 lbs

or more.   They shaved him as usual upset him

[top torn off the page]
where he was met by the Negroes who served him 
almost as bad as the carpenter.  The next one
caught was myself. The barbers rasped my face
with their iron hoops mort unmercifully and 
then almost blinded me with the stuff called
lather made of ashes lamp black greese and salt
water. And if I shuld open my mouth to take
breath in went a brush and when half blind
and half smothered they upset me into the
water which was about 4 feet deep where
I was most unmercifully ducked (or as it is called 
washed off) with the engine playing full in my
face. And no way to get rid of it.  After
half drounding me I was let off.  Went
below and changed clothes determined to enjoy
the fun. (The worst of all this was that Mr & Mrs
W with their pretty daughter was up on the horse
block laughing fit to kill themselves.) After I 
had been served in this way and some 6 or 8

Others in the same way some even worse if possible. Neptune's guards then secured the prisoner who kicked and scuffled but twas no use.   they shaved ducked and washed the poor fellow till he could not speak then came about 150 men who were shaved &c after this.  A party of Mids got up a plan to shave Neptune himself & a few others. it commenced on the boom cover by som one taking the hose and spurting if - [crossed out: full] in his face another went around and upset the bench with all the barbers in it over into the water another took the bucket of lather and hove it over old Neptune who had to run for it.   The Capt attempted to inter[?] but was as badly ducked as any one. at the close there was about 10 mids in the water 20 old sailors and a Philadelphia exquisite  M' W feet under all almost drowned  And his

dignity most outrageously insulted.  The noise and roars of laughter the splashing of water and the half strangled oath of some poor fellow  as the engine played in his face. the dirty faces of the sufferers and the uncouth figures of Neptune's barbers. made this one of the most laughable scenes I ever witnessed. After it was all over I found that I had suffered more than any one else. my coat was split up the back and one tail torn off- my shirt ripped off my back and one leg of my pants torn off above the knee. Mrs.W & family appeared to enjoy the fun more than any one else and when they caught a sight of me as I dove down the hatch, I heard the clear laugh of Mr. W's Pretty daughter who called to  her mother to look but twas too late. I was out of sight   when nearly every one on board had been ducked in some way or other. the Capt ordered the Boatswain to call all hands & splice the main Brace which was done. A good dinner was given in the cabin. The day ended without accident (if we except a few tipsy men).   The Weather on the line is nearly all ways squally with frequent calms. the reason I suppose is this that the NE trades meeting the SE trades.

counterbalance each other and the vapour carried thence by each trade condensing cause the almost perpetual rains which they have on the line.   For several days after crossing the line nothing seen except a few Porpoises and one or two grampus whale.  All [?...ing?] getting the ship in good order for Rio.   August 1st  spoke the U.S. ship Erie homeward bound sent a letter bag on board of her.  She had Hon Mr Pendleton on board as passenger.  (the ex-minister to Chile).  From the Mid who boarded us learned that the Mid in the Pacific squadron were by no means pacific for there had been some 3 or 4 duels fought in the course of as Many months, the next day showed our coulors to a French Man-of-war proved to be the Bereau the same vessel we sailed in company with from Santa Cruz.  discovered land ahead.  August 3d  Standing in for the harbour of Rio De Janiero the land off to the S of Rio has a very singular appearance.  it appears like an immense giant laid out at full length.  his  head to the S

his head is a large hill or rather mountain some 12 or 1500 feet high. A large white granite rock forms his eye.  a high hill on this mountain makes a good representation of a roman nose, a deep chasm his mouth and another hill his chin. his body is formed of a long range of hills nearly level on top. his feet is the sugar loaf (which is at the mouth of the Harbour) a hill 1200 feet high and almost perpendicular  his arms appear to lay along side of him. When near under the land got a strong land breezes the night being quite dark the Capt ordered a Night look out to be kept.  Cape Frio is a  high land to the N' & E' of the Sugarloaf.   it has a good revolving light on it near the mouth of the harbour are several small islands, on one of them is a beautiful light, There is no difficulty in going into Rio for there is pleanty of water not requiring a pilot even in the night. There
is a strong current setting to the S' from Cape Frio. At the entrance of the Harbour is about 1 mile wide. There are three strong forts.  At the mouth of the Harbour one on each side

and one in the middle on a small island.  farther up in another fort also on an island and to judge from appearances should think they were very strong. Then there is another fort on an island called (?cohas?) just in front of the town on this island is the Public arsenal and English store houses. This fort has but 6 or 8 guns Mounted at present, and has but a small guard of soldiers. It was on the north side of this Island that Capt Cook hove his ships down. There is now an old ring of an Anchor fastened in the rocks and left here by him. We found the Frigates Raritan and Congress laying here they are both fine vessels. Frigates of the 1st class. They are both very fast sailers tis said tis said that the Raritan logged 276 miles in 24 hours and for three successive days 240 miles. The English also have two fine Frigates laying here one of them (The America) was built in the United States and presented to the French. She was taken from the French

during the last war. The Harbour of Rio is one of the largest and finest in the world. It has some 15 or 20 pretty islands in it and besides it extends up some 20 or 30 miles in the country. It is surrounded on all sides by high mountains and is one of the most picturesque harbours in South America   Rio contains about 280,000 inhabitants. This includes the two small towns of Port Raza and Rio Grand which are on the opposite side of the bay. The Principal exports of the Brazils are coffe sugar & Hides. The slave trade is not recognized by the government but is winked at by its officers. The English have an old Hulk laying off that island in which they keep such Negroes as are taken by their cruisers.  From this ship they are apprenticed out for a number of years to learn trades &c and as many of them or rather all of them know nothing but what they are told they generally die in slavery. Jnº Bull takes their wages at the first off start to take care of it for them.  and as the usual

custom is to report the Negro or Negroes dead in a year or so afterwards. The English officers can do no more and the money paid their commissioners thus goes to the government. The same plan is followed up in Havanna & Matanzas and in every port that the English have a slave hulk. Brazil has an Emperor Don Pedro ll. his power is limited by a sort of parlement. The Brazils once belonged to Portugal but Don Pedro The 1st being obliged to leave his country on account of the French invasion during the French Revolution. Transferred at the same time the seat of Government to Rio. After the peace Don Pedro vacated the throne of Portugal to his Daughter and then place his son at the head of the Brazilian Empire  In the interior of Brazil in the most celebrated dimond country in the World it is about 100 miles in extent. It always has a strong guard of soldiers in and around it. Rio is mostly built of granite  the houses being built generally two stories

high and then white washed, they are usually flat-on top. The streets are very narrow. And as usual in Portugese places dirty. The churches are well built and gaudily dressed.
The convents are large prison looking places, there is a fine opera house and also a good theatre,   Rio is a sort of half way house between the North Atlantic and the Pacific and Indian Oceans. Ships rarely pass without putting in for fresh water and provisions I have understood that this government and that of Buenos Ayres are about going to war 
on a boundary question.  The Prince of Naples who Married the Emperors daughter tis said is to take command of the Brazilian Navy  There is now on board of the Raritan & Congress two Brazilian mids and two lieutenants, who have permission to go to sea in the above named vessels to see how duty is carried on. (The day we came in appeared to me to be some grand Holliday with them)  after was learned that it was the Empress' birth day  there was some 800 or 1000 guns fired almost filling the harbour with smoke

and echoing amongst the hills like the loudest thunder  10th the Prince of Naples visited the various ships in the Harbour was saluted with 21 guns by each vessel both in going on board and leaving  they manning yards at the same time,  not a day elapsed but that some 8 or 10 salutes were fired and some-times 20 or 30.)  The government of Brazil and Buenos Ayres were at war some 10 or 15 years ago.  The Brazilian appeared to have got the worst of it, as numerous privateers were fitted out in Baltimore for the Buenos Ayrean Service Manned by American seamen.   The Reason the privateers took the side of the Buenos Ayreans was simply this that they, the B. Ayreans had no commerce and of course could loose nothing whilst the Brazilians had  very considerable commerce and were almost without men of war and those few they did have, no one cared for.  a short time since the Province of Rio Grand rebelled the Emperor is now busy sending troops to quell the insurrection

a number of years since an American commodore sent his crew ashore on liberty in Rio.  Some of his men were pressed into the Brazillian service  the Commodore demanded them.  at first he was refused.  The Old Fellow got Springs on his cables and again demanded them with the threat that if they were not on board in one hour he would knock the town down.  They were off in half the time.  August 20th  we now have been here nearly a month the shore under our noses and not one of us allowed to visit it.  it is the hardest part of our lot to be refused to go on shore.  one's feet feel so good when they get on terra firma after being confined 50 or 60 days on board ship   I sometimes fancy how a prisoner must feel when released.  I think it is very much like a mid after his Quarantine is out.  Our Capt is very kind with this exception.  And says we shall not go on shore till we are out of debt.  he does not care how much we wish to go.  he says no to it.  For My own part I want to go ashore very badly  I want [?]

August 21st  A ball was given on shore to which we were all invited.  I asked the Capt he kindly consented to allow us to go.  We went and spent a very agreeable evening.  The Rio girls are (some of them) very pretty  Some of them are rather dark but all appeared good looking and some beautiful to me for I had not see a pretty girl for 20 days.  or rather I had not seen a female for that length of time, and of course thought the laughing giddy girls of Rio were beautiful ,  one of our Mids (pretty much of a democrat) went up to the Princess of Naples who is a beautiful woman and called her Mrs Naples requesting her to dance with him it was done for a Joke.  August 24th The U.S. Squadron consisting of the Raritan the Congress the Frigate United States & the Brig Bainbridge it is expected they will return shortly as this voyage is intended as a sort of race with the U. States.  She being one of fastest sailer in the wold [sic] and the Congress & Raritan are both hard to beat.

we had a dinner party given to us by Mr Wise the other day it was a very pleasant affair he made us all feel as if he were at home and in short acted the Virginia gentleman out and out.   Sept 3d  The Frigate Congress came in and anchored according to her accounts she beat the Frigate United States & Raritan. but we all disposed to doubt it.  Sept 10th  at sea we left Rio on the morning of the 8th with a fair wind after getting outside the weather became squally with a thick hazy atmosphere.  gave chase to a suspicious looking brig overhaul'd her showed English colors she showed Spanish in return so as we are opposed to searching other vessels than our own Nation or in other words opposed to the right of search we let her pass.   The Weather continued moderate until the 15th when it became squally but passed off without accident.   The Weather we all found getting colder at every move we made to the Southward we now found it to be quite unpleasant   As the change was so sudden from the hot sultry weather between the tropics and the cold or rather cool winds

of the temperate zone  20th   Lat 32º S. Long 25 west   this day being calm and pleasant weather  Such of us as  had the watch below amused our selves in catching the birds which were hovering around the ship in every direction.   Most of them being Cape Pidgeons  a white bird not quite as large as a hawk being almost entirely white with the exception of their back and wings which are black spotted.  besides these the Cape hens wre very numerous.   The Cape hens are larger than the Pidgeons and as black as crows.  Then the albatros as large as the largest size geese and some tis said are 12  to 16 feet from tip to tip.   They are almost white the method of catching them is with a large  size fish hook and a piece of fat pork towed overboard   it will scarcely ever be overboard more than 10 minutes before some of them will nab it.  We all thought we would have a fine mess of fresh grub but they (the birds) were so fishy that no one could more than [?shuck?] of it.  I had just as soon eat so much sperm oil as to eat one of them.  During the day we exercised the crew at firing at a target  there was some very pretty shots fired.  the target was

placed about 2 miles from the ship.  The Weather growing colder every day   Many Men were on the list with colds coughs &c.  we have been remarkably lucky since we have been out this time   Not having more than 2 hours head wind during the whole time.   Sept 21st  being my birthday manage to raise a good dinner for our mess which was acceptable to our mess.  As we all felt hard up for a little good grub.  Sept 23d  Discovered the island of Tristan d' Acunha on our lee bow.  squared away for it   The island of Tristan d'Acunha is situated in 12º05' W Long and 37º 07 s lat.  it was Discovered by a Portugese Capt of the Same Name  there is also two other islands on called Nightingale isle and the other inaccessable island.  The island of Tristan D;Acuhna is about 8000 feet high and during six months of the year is covered with now.  Since the year 1805 it has been inhabited by some 18 or 20 persons mostly English and Americans  The island appears to be of volcanic origin on the north side of the isle is a fast watering place where whalers frequently put in for fresh water.  [crossed out  The shore along about 1100 feet] the land next the sea shore is about 1000 feet

above the levil of the sea when it spreads off into
beautiful table land which is said to be very fertile
from near the centre of the island rises the peak
almost like a sugar loaf, the family who first
settled this island were by the name of Glass the
father of the family was an English-man and
from all accounts an upright and honorable man
They raise potatoes and onions which they manage
to sell to  [crossed out: the] Whalers. they prefer trading for clothing
or spirits which they find of use [crossed out: to them] whilst 
money is perfectly useless to them,  in 1836 they had
several life boats which were kept for the purpose of 
assisting vessels that might drive on shore during
the heavy gales which usually blow off here,  There is
anchorage to be had on the North side of the isle in
30 faths water.  About half mile from the shore, tho it
is very unsafe during this season of the year for according
to the best accounts the NE and NW winds prevail
during this season, During the last war with England
this was the cruising ground of the Peacock, An English
frigate once watered ship at this isle she did
it by sending her Casks ashore filling them

and having hauling lines attached with which she hauled them on board, some 10 or 12 years since a fine East India ship was wrecked on Nightingale isle where a great many of her crew were lost, and the survivors suffered almost incredible hard-ships.  They however managed to build a small boat from pieces of the wreck whith [sic] which some two or three managed to reach the island of Tristan d'Acunha, from whence they sent a large life boat for the survivors.  they remained in the last named island 8 or 10 months before they got off.  during which time old Gov Glass treated them with great kindness.  During the imprisonment of Bonaparte on the isle of St Helena the English made Tristan d'Acunha to sort of rendezvous for all their men of-war.  but since his death they have deserted it.  in 1820 an English man of war touched at inaccessable island which is called so from the quantity of cane growing on it.  they found 5 American [?sealers?] who had been on the isle 6 or 8 months and were very patiently waiting for the return of their Vessel.  Som [sic] 4 or 5 years after another vessel touched at these islands.  the [sic] found 4 graves with inscriptions on them and the fifth man laying in a hut which they had built for their comfort.  it was thought that the vessel which they belonged to had been lost and that all had died one after another leaving the island as

desolate and dreary as ever.  it is almost impossible to conceive the situation of these men cut off from the wold [sic] and having but faint hopes of ever returning to their friends mothers or brothers who no doubt overhauled every News Paper to see if the [crossed out: long]  lost [crossed out:  brother] had yet arrived.  but horrible as it may seem to be with 4 other persons alone on a desolate island in the middle of the the [sic] ocean, yet how much more so must it be to loose [sic] there 4 companions and be left alone without a single soul to converse with and feel that you are alone.  and how painful must have been the last sad office of burying his last companion. and how lonely and lonesome was his prayer no doubt offered from the heart and soul as he heaped the earth upon his last friend.  During the night we ran down close to the island of Tristan d"Acunha  (to within 2 or 3 miles) we then hove to with our fore topsail aback waiting for day light that we might send our boat, ashore.  it was during our watch on deck (the 2d watch) and near 4 AM.  the weather all [crossed out:  day] night had looked squally. and now had become so black and dark that it was difficult to get about without stumbling, or falling down.  it had been blowing a stiff breeze all night when it lulled [crossed out:  down] so that

the sails flapped against the mast. but suddenly the land appeared to be obscured in a cloud or fog and we had hardly time to clew down the topsails and up helm before it struck as we ran off before it close reefed the topsails and furled every thing else that it still blowing fresher there were at length furled and the Main Topsail set under which we hove to during all this time 6 or 8 hours it hailed and rained not down on us but against us the rain driving it before it in horizontal lines.  it blew so that I could not hear the officer of the deck 20 steps from him.  for two days more we lay on the waves with nothing but a main topsail set and sometimes under bare poles.  then the gale commenced Moderating and as a matter of course the sea commenced rising the ship heretofore made about 1 inch in 24 hours but with a sea on which threatened every moment to sweep us we made 18 inches,  it was a grand tho fearful sight to see the waves at such a highth [sic] and a pretty sight to see our good old ship riding them like a duck tho sometimes pitching her Cat heads under water.  One of the Forecastle men a good old sailor

was out on the sprit sail yard doing something or other that his duty required when a sea struck us & washed him overboard.  the next wave fortunately washed him up so that he caught by the end of a rope hanging out of the fore Chains; if he had not caught nothing could have saved him as the sea was to [sic] rough to lower a boat without instantly swamping her.  After the gale we made sail for the [?Came?] cracking on as much as we could carry for the Cape determined to leave these rough latitudes.  We had a fresh and fair wind until the present time  Sept. 30th  head winds and squally  we found a current to the Northward of Tristan d"Acunha and to the S in lat 40 we found another setting in an opposite direction.  The 1st was about 15 miles per 24 hours to the W and the second appeared to be a sort of Eddie current about 10 miles per day to the E. during this and two or three preceding days we saw a number of whales and this morning I observed an entirely different kind of bird to any that I had heretofore seen being smaller than the Cape Pidgeon and larger than the Mother Cary Chicken and a pretty dove color [?(White at?] First in d'Acunha we spoke an english ship bound to the

east indies. and today we spoke an American whaler bound on a cruise to the Pacific ocean. The weather still unpleasant and cold the gun deck with deck storage ward room sick bay and every other place below the spar deck wet and uncomfortable whilst on the spar deck it blew a half gale of wind with cold rains every two or three hours so that none of us had any great comfort to [?hang?] on besides I had got into a peck of trouble with my mess mates who kicked up a devil of a row because I would not give them  scouse for dinner and meat for supper. wishing I suppose to eat up every thing to day and luck for tomorrow, it being a common saying in a steerage of go day come day god send Sunday. All of us begin to want to see the land and many a long talk does my self and watchmates have about home with the pleasant things that have happened there and what we would do and say if we were at home but we have only to look up to see that we are a long long way off from our homes for these the bright stars that bear to the southward of our homes are nearly out of sight in the north and new &

and strange stars show themselves in the South.  the North star has long since been shut from our sight and who knows when we will see it again.  sometimes I think that when I do get sight of it again that I would almost fall down and worship it.  I know that it will be a happy sight it will be like meeting an old friend for I am sure its face will appear familiar and then to know that one is looking at the same star that his friends mothers or sisters are looking at makes him feel like he was near home.  Three days ago we crossed the Meridian of Greenwich and are now in East long.  Oct 2  Still rough squally and unpleasant weather  the Barometer falling and every appearance of a gale.  a heavy sea on and when down between two seas they hide the horizon on either side and sometimes even as high up as 35º in the heavens   Oct 3.  blowing a gale ship under close reefed main topsail and Fore Stormstaysail during the night carried away the Cross jack yard in three pieces and sprung the fore yard.  The Weather working squally secured every thing for a gale got on preventer [?] the ship labouring very heavily and groaning

like she was in distress.  passed a large Merchant man hove to under Main Topsail and storm staysail.  4th  Doubled the Cape.  it appears that we have had the best luck that a ship ever had since leaving New York we have not had all together more than six days head winds and now we are pushing along under a close reefed main topsail at the rate of 10 miles or more per hour.  Doubling the Cape is no unimportant undertaking.  Many a poor fellow has beat about here against the heavy south east gales for days and weeks and even for Months at a time and many a stout ship has been obliged to call all hands to the pumps and keep away for St Augustin bay in Madagascar where sometimes they would arrive with their crews almost worn out with fatigue and Many have never arrived at al.  There is but few persons but have heared of the Flying Dutchman.  Many a tough yarn is told of the old fellow and no doubt many more will be told.  Many singular appearances have been seen about these latitudes which have never been accounted for, in 1820 the English government sent a surveying ship out to survey the South Coast of Africa with the

adjacent coat and islands (Capt Owen) he has the following story which can not be questioned as to its truth but as it is tells better for its self in its own words than in any other I shall give it you word for word.  Viz.  For many years the flying Dutchman has been a popular superstition with mariners.  few have often passed the Cape but they can tell the tale of what they saw or of what others have told them.  Old Seamen still while away the tedeious night watch repeating to their young and marvel loving comerades, stories of this water sprite and many a stout heart has quailed as with anxious ears they have listened to the peaks of this airy terror   The following circumstance happened to us which called forth many an almost forgotten record of the flying dutchman in the evening of the 6th of April when off port Danger the Barracouta was seen about 2 miles to leeward.  Struck with the irregularity of her being so soon after us we at first concluded that it could not be she.  but the peculiarity of her rigging and other circumstances convinced us that we were not mistaken Nay so distinctly was she seen that many well known

faces could be seen on deck looking towards our ship  After keeping thus for some time we became surprised that she made no effort to join us.  but on the contrary stood away but being so near the port to which we were both destined Capt Owen did not attach much importance to this proceeding and we accordingly continued our course  At sunset she hove too sent a boat away apparently to pick up a man over-board  during the night we could see no light.  next morning we anchored in Simon bay where we waited for a whole week anxiously expecting her arrival and it afterwards appeared that she was over 300 miles from us at the time.  he further adds that the above might have been caused by some simple & natural tho known cause and suggests the idea that it might have been caused by refraction.  Many strange things happen at sea which ignorant and superstitious sailors view with dread.   Dr [?Arnold?] mentions in his excellent work on philosophy of ships being seen sailing keel up amongst the clouds off Cape Horn and ascribes it to refraction & reflection.   he also mentions the circumstance of a vessel out of sight of land off Cape [?] some 60 or 70 hours sail

from Rio De Janeiro.  he says that about noon they were all very much alarmed by the ringing of Bells which appeared to be at a great distance off but it was remarked that these Bells could only be heared in one Place Viz immediately under the spanker.  And when they arrived in Rio they mentioned the above circumstance. and were told that all the bells in Rio were that day tolling or rather ringing and Dr. Arnott accounts for it by Saying or rather supposing that the sound striking the [?concave?] surface of the spanker was reflected back to a focus and that in that focus the bells could be heard & no where else,  Oct 4th  we are now to the eastward of the Cape of Good-Hope  With a heavy gale of wind driving us a head so that we have but little doubt of being in warm and pleasant weather in a few days in fact from present indications show that we will soon have good weather.  Amongst sea fairing people doubling the Cape of Good hope is considered a dangerous and hardy undertaking the reason is this that during the Winter the Westerly Gales blow very heavy and there is always a strong current setting around the Cape to the W varying from 2 miles to 7 per hour.  And the wind & sea being in opposite directions kick up a heavy &

high cross sea making the stoutest vessels groan and creak incessantly  by keeping close in shore a vessel usually may avoid the heavy swell and the strong current but is liable to have a lee shore if the wind should haul to the south.  Near the Cape is the well known banks of Agulhas tis said fine fish and plenty of them may be caught off these banks resembling very much those caught on the Banks of New Foundland.  but owing to the restrictions which are imposed on all but English vessels and owing to the continual bad weather off the Coast and the want of harbours and places to cure their fish but few persons make it a business and these are usually lascars or Arabs.  The Many accidents that fishermen are exposed to such as ship wreck &c is another reason that it is not more closely followed.  for shipwreck on the coast of Africa is either Death or perpetual slavery.  Tho many who have been wrecked are redeemed by their friends or by some good christian but by far the greater part end their days in Slavery.  From Sept to April the SE winds are said to prevail but we found strong west and NW gales on our passage round.  and during June July and August Westwardly gales blow almost

constantly many ships have been lost in these terrible gales according to Horsburgh and other writers these gales are nearly always announced by a black heavy cloud in the West with lightning in the north and sounds of distant thunder besides this the Barometer is generally more than usually agitated and sinks quite low.   These appearances are almost immediately followed by a heavy squall and sometimes a whirlwind some times these gales blow with great force with a clear sky but these are not considered dangerous as they blow steady and there is but little danger of being taken aback.  When the Dutch had a considerable trade with the east and were at that time a great commercial nation their vessels being seen in every sea with a broom at their mast heads meaning that they could sweep the seas of every thing and in fact when she was at her greatest glory they had a large East-india Company their stopping place being Cape town.  there Dutch Commanders dreaded this Cape More than any other and Many prefered [sic] doubling Cape Horn and crossing the Pacific than trusting themselves to this ugly Cape.  the following precautions were used by their

commanders. viz when the wind at SE or S & E shifted to NE to take in the main sail and if lightning appeared in the NW [?near?] ship and shorten sail for if lightning was seen in that quarter they expected the gale to commence with the usual whirlwind which would be fatal if taken aback.  The Mercury is seldom ever disturbed by a sudden squal [sic] which  are not uncommon in these latitudes.   We found in crossing the Banks of Agulhas  the water 6, 8 & 10 degrees colder than off soundings and the Water slightly discolored.   We sounded in 80 & 100 faths found bottom, Lightning is very frequent and dangerous to the S and E of this bank. and to the Long of the South end of Madagascar.  Two East India Men the Brittania and Bombay Castle were struck some years since killing some 4 or 5 persons in each the vessels only were saved by cutting away their fore masts which fortunately fell clear of the ship in a mass of fire.   Another ship the Thames homeward bound laying to with the wind at W with hard squalls and showers of hail a high sea and much lightning all around was struck by several fire balls killing 5 persons and shocking others  very severely.

the Telemaque shoals are said to exist in Lat 38º 24' S.  38º 50' E.   Many shoals laid down on our charts are no doubt false.  Vessels frequently mistaking schools of fish for shoals and Dead Whales for rocks.  According to the journals of some ships old cruisers there are immense sea Monsters in the southern ocean regular Jonah swallowers.  the Ship Hercules journal says that man at mast head reported land thought it must be [?] Van Campbells shoal weather being good thought we would have a good look at it accordingly steered for it shortly after man at mast head reported another small island on the other bow and directly after saw another directly ahead whilst in the act of hauling away from them saw them suddenly disappear showing an immense fish tail of a white grayish color it was covered with barnacles and seaweed like a wreck which had been in the water a long time.   these immense monsters lay on the water with their heads about 16 feet above water and the sea breaking

on them we could not tell the length of them but it must have been immense from the discolored water seen over them if they had not moved we should certainly have reported land & shoals when we arrived in port.  This and many other hard yarns are told of the south sea Monsters.  Honberg one of the oldest East india Capts says that no doubt many of these fish have been mistaken for rocks and shoals and marked on the Chart accordingly.  The Atmosphere is remarkably clear off Cape of Good Hope and in fact over the whole of the South Atlantic and Indian Oceans.  Venus and even Jupiter can be frequently seen at noon when the sun is shining brightly.   Oct 10th  weather pretty with a blue sky a pleasant wind.  11th  the weather still beautiful the wind very light with a clear blue sky the sea as smooth as a mill pond.  the stars as bright as so many dimonds [sic].   lat    29º S. 37º 15' E. Long.   Most vessels doubling the Cape have found a strong current setting to the S' & W'  Many ships have missed their reconing 60 & 80 miles per day and others 30 & 40.  whilst we tried the current and found none.   Oct 15th  At 8 A.M. whilst our mess were sitting down to their breakfast we were all joyfully surprised by the cry of

land O'  on the evening previous it blew a fresh gale with flying clouds and a clear sky.  close reefed the fore and main topsails and furled the mizzen and hove to the sea which had been very smooth became rough and short.  during the night. discovered a light a head which soon disappeared.  At 8 AM discovered the land of Cape St. Mary (the south end of Madagascar) bearing E by S per compass.  the land appeared to be low with scrubby bushes and a white sandy beach.  breaks are very numerous and long reef of rocks appear to extend almost as far as one could see and about 2 miles of the beach.  these reefs are usually coral and rise up almost perpendicularly from the bottom of the sea on them some times the sea breakes on them some places it is just deep enough to knock a ships bottom out and too deep to break.  Whilst along side of these rocks no bottom can be found with 100 fath. we coasted up along the land which appeared to be almost a desert   the beach white sand and the hills rough rocky & barren looking with a kind of stumpy growth on them.   They all appear to be a formation of sand and limestone.  during the whole day kept the lead going  16th  Sounded every half

hour found sometimes 50 faths and a few minutes after get 8 & 10 with the hand lead.  tho there had been a fresh breeze all day there  was but little sea on and the surf in side of the breakers did no roll too heavily for a boat to land if well managed.  with the glass could see any quantity of natives following us up picking up shells and gazing at us with great curiosity, pointing and moving their arms as if greatly excited.   At 5 PM the water shoaling rapidly came to off Sandy Island.  to the S of Sandy island is a point of land which extends out a great distance in the sea  it is quite low.  The sandy isle above mentioned is very low and on the n' end of the island to the nw about 2 miles is a line of coral reefs over which the breakes violently on each side of it is a bank or shoal on which very fine fish are caught by the Natives.  The entrance to St. Augustin bay is by no means difficult the entrance laying to the W'd with plenty of water and from 10 AM till sun set the sea breezes blows fresh whilst from mid to 8 AM the land breezes blows off shore.  so there is but little trouble going in

or coming out.    The bottom is generally coral the is some places it is white sand. and near the anchorage or off Tent Rock it is a kind of black mud.  a first rate holding ground.  Oct 17th 1844.  saw several native canoes at a distance and one or two near at hand hoisted a white flag, but none of them appeared willing to come on board served out fishing lines to all the messes.  some of the men caught a few very fine fish which were great to a lot of half famished mortals.  Soon after breakfast we got underway and stood down for the anchorage sending boats ahead to sound.  they found an average depth of 15 faths. up to the anchorage off tent Rock called so from its resemblance to a tent.   we had hardly anchored before several native Canoes came along-side  the first two with the Princes of the adjoining country. viz Prince Johny Green and Prince Willie   when within hail of the ship Johny Green (being quite [?gassey?] man and trading so much with the American and English had learned to talk English quite rapidly) sung out  Sip roy (ship Ahoy)  What you cum frum, what you live, wat you wantee, you wantee the bullucs,

de shepee(Sheep) de water, de woodee, You sabee (know) me, me sabee you.  You likee me.  Me likee you.  you fren Me.  Me fren you.  You presentee me.  Me presentee you.  My namee Johny Green  Me big man  Me prince.  Me sabie Sipy John Adams.  Capt Halober (Conover)  After repeating this over two or three times as loud as he could bawl, he paddled along side in his Canoe and Came on board.   Along with Prince Willie who was a very old man and very quiet, with them Came 4 or 5 others of the royal family.  going after they all shook hands with the Captain and kept up an incessant jabbering.  Prince Johny Green was a man of about 30 years of age.  quite straight and well formed with long [?heels?] thick lips flat nose and hair not kinky but wooly and a skin somewhat between the Negroe and indian but rather more of the Negroe than otherwise.  his left eye to use his own words for it was no see wun bit.  French sogar jab him out wid muskit.  this left eye was entirely closed and at 10 steps one could hardly tell whether there had ever been an eye there or not.  his other eye was a large clear Hack rolling eye moving as quick as thought and appeared to be on all sides

of him at one time the whiteness of the white part of the ball contrasted strangely with the blackness of his skin.   this one eye with a constant grin showing his ivory fore and aft with the quick ludicrous pronunciation of English made him quite agreeable.   His dress was something after Joseph of old for he had a shirt of many colors.  made of white cotton blue cotton. yellow flannel. red flannel. white flannel.  blue flannel gray [?kannet?] and blue cloth. and the whole so dirty that you could hardly distinguish the intersection of the colors.  on his shoulder was an old epaulett which had been given to him by Capt Conover whilst the John Adams was in at this place.  on his head was an old hat as dirty and greasy as it well could be  he wore [?] ear rings but wore no breeches or trousers.  but had an old rag tied around him which he called the colote.  from his hips down he was perfectly naked.  he carried a spear made for the double purpose of thrusting or throwing.  on his back was an old American Eagle which had been given to him some Marine and he mounted any quantity of American Navy buttons on his Joseph's shirt.  his hair was cut off

close to his head.  on account he said of the death of his father who died one moon ago.  this was a token of his grief besides this he had killed on his fathers grave ten bullocks or buffaloes, ten cows & ten sheep  the horns of these he buried near his fathers feet in order he said that when he got to heaven to show God that he was a rich man.  besides the meat of the above were considered provisions for him on his journey  they also buried his spear musket pipe and colote with him.  When asked where his father had gone he always pointed up.  he said that in some parts of the island when big man die, kille de bullucks, kille de shepe, killed de slave o' kille ebery tin.  he always wound up his remarks by saying me fren of you you fren of me  spose you gib me buttin.  Prince Willie was a man of about 60 with a gray head and beard (being the only one in the island that I saw who could raise any beard at all.)  was quite still and dignified wore an old pepper and salt coat, trousers that come down just above his knees  he wore also an American Naval Cap.  his face was rather sour looking than otherwise.   he kept his hair well

greased.  he was continually stroking his beard of which he seamed [sic] quite proud.  The Capt invited all the royal family below set them all around the table and took his seat near the head.  his white silvery hair showing to great advantage amongst the black skins and wooly heads around him.  Stationed around the Cabin was a number of boys with drawn swords (to keep the royal family from stealing for from the king down they al fancy a hap nail or belaying pin a glass tumbler or any other little odd or end which may lay in their way)  it was a pretty sight and thoughts of Columbus and Penn were busy in my mind.  one or two of them were very busy all the time viewing their beautiful faces in the Capts Mirror.  After their confab they were sent on deck.  when shortly after they left the ship whilst they were on board we got up the band and played several tunes for them (by this time 50 or 60 men women and children).  when the band struck up the first note they all stopped gazed with open mouths and eyes whilst others made a bolt for the gangway and tried to get clear of the ship  they all seemed

filled with amazement.  but when they struck off with [? ] they were perfectly enchanted.  And most of the women struck up a Malagarki dance they brought many kind of shells with them but most of them uncleaned tho I bought several pretty ones already cleaned.  for a button a-piece and three or 4 for a cotton handkerchief.  They always kept up a great noise and asked always a dollar for the smallest trifle tho they would take a button, a piece of old Iron hoop or any thing else civilized.  Tho the greatest things with them was jack knives beads and gun powder,  Many of them bought along side pumkins potatoes (sweet) beans and a few fish, those usually in such small quantities that is was difficult for a large mess to get enough.  We had as much as we could do watching the natives who came on board to prevent them from stealing priming wires and in fact any small articles that they could lay their hands to    The next day 18th Oct having got out all boats dispatched them for wood and water.  The Watering place bears about East from the anchoring ground

the  channel is quite narrow on the bar the tide rises 13 feet and at low water only 2 or 3 feet water on [crossed out: the bar] it. so that is quite a difficult matter to wood and water as a westerly wind always makes a heavy swell and during the Ebb it breaks furiously.  We found a small french Schooner and also a French brig trading with the Natives for Tortoise shell.  [?] beans. Shells. and many other articles too numerous to mention.  in return she gave them old muskets that would hardly stand fire. condemned powder, beads and blue cotton cloth.  the watering place is 6 miles from tent rock.  At high tide the water is rather brackish but at low tide is quite fresh tho muddy and having a taste something like milk and water.  We had scarcely been on the land 2 Moments before we were surrounded by the natives.  Men and women  the men with their long keen well ballanced spears. and with no other clothing but a colote.  the women nearly as naked as the men the only differance [sic] being that the Women wore a sort of shirt over their shoulders and besides

many of them carried a child on their backs.  without exception I think the Malagash women are the ugliest I ever saw.  Many of them disgustingly dirty to boot.  the first thing I heared on getting out of the boat was sposee you gib me buttin  Me fren of you &c.  We had to cut our own wood which we did without trouble as there was an abundance near and arround [sic]  us.  the  only trouble being to get it to the boat after it was cut.  The growth of the surrounding country appeared to be Mostly tamerind and gum trees of a kind that I had never seen before.  Also a tree bearing a fruit very much like an orange.  This the natives told us was a great charm and that to handle it was almost certain death.
