The Naturalist handled them with impunity but was confidently assured that he would die.  he pronounced it a poison.  A curious tree grows on and near the river resembling a green fodder stack a kind of cabbage tree.  the Natives used it for various purposes. viz thatching their huts making mats &c.  A small kind of cane also grows on the river resembling very much the American cane with this differance, [sic] that this had a small briar on it

which stung very painfully.
Dear Bob.
Near San Augustin bay is extensive marshes which render the place very unhealthy to strangers.   The Natives were very troublesome wishing to sell us any-thing and every-thing they had besides this the men were continually off in the bushes with the women.  They always made bargains with the men giving a button or a jack knife when they would send one of they concubines with the sailor in the bush.   Many of them wished the officers to stay with their 2nd Class Wives asking at the same time for a button or ring.  Our Proffessor [sic] a very fat man went on shore he was instantly surrounded by Natives who slapped him on the belly and asked if he had picinniny dare.  and the women could not be convinced that he was not a woman till they felt with their hands when they said un eate plenti de bullocks   the same happened to our Marine officer who was also a very fat man.  during our Stay I did not see a single native that had more flesh on him than ordinary.   Most of them being in good order but not fat.   A village of a dozen or two huts was near the watering place.   Several of he Mids went up

with the husbands of the women what happened I can not say but most of them come back with the buttons cut off the tails of their coats.
[double line drawn apparently indicating the end of the section "To Bob"]
Capt Jim was the head man of the village near us, a large well made man with a cunning treacherous look and a bad character.  Every evening a boat was sent for the wood cutters who returned on board.  we nearly always got on ground going off as the channel being quite narrow and the Ebb tide running out we could not fall off either way without getting aground so that we nearly always had to back out.  the same thing happened over day after day.  I had been detailed for the first cutter.  She had had a picked crew of the best men in the ship a fine boat on leaving the ship every man was required to take a cutlass but the Natives being so friendly it was sometimes neglected.   We usually made two trips per day.  on going up and coming back the first time we had to pull but the second trip was usually attended with the sea breezes with which we sailed up.  one time in going up we saw an immense shark 10 or 15 feet long the boat ran just over him

just out of reach of a boat hook which one of the men attempted to thrust into him.  every day the natives came down in droves increasing every day bringing with them sheep chickens goats potatoes beans and pumpkins.  These they traded for buttons rings beads powder &c  besides these they had a great many buffaloe or cattle.  these they sold for a [?trife?]:  Asking $10 in Money but taking 4 bbs of powder for the best of them.  The Native wear around their wrists and ancles [sic] silver rings some of them weighing two or three ounces.   These they sell to the traders on the coast who usually buy them for 50 cts worth of Cotton Cloth.  Several things were stolen from the men. and the longer we staid the more troublesome they became.   One of our men accidentally broke one of their spears, the Native snatched up another and was with difficulty kept from throwing it into him.   They evinced a disposition to quarrell with the boats crew and having found that tamarinds were in demand the would not let us gather them but would gather them themselves in order to sell to us.  Many of them (carried Muskkets

I saw some of them firing them Manner is this viz. sticking the spear down at arms length they rest the musket on their left hand holding it across his body with the muzzle pointing to the left.  the lock held off from their body and the breech at arms length  they point it by mere guess shutting their eyes when they fire.     Oct. 18th   still watering ship.  Took my rifle up with me shot some curious birds.  amongst them a kind of black Hawk.  also a black bird with red wings.  and a sort of black Crow with a white ring around their necks.  The Natives were very much surprised when they saw me kill a hawk about 80 yds.  they expressed their surprise by putting their open hands over the mouth with the palm down opening their eyes and making a sound something like ugh.   All of them wished to buy it some offering me 10 & others 20 bullocks.  One of the men put his hand into a basket and took a tamirind.  the Natives who sought every opportunity flew into a great rage dancing and yelling brandishing their spears and evidently greatly excited.  the other natives in the woods came flocking in and most

of them joining in the song and dance.  Every one expected something was about to take place in the way of a fight and had it not have been for the coolness of our men who were drawn  up ready I have but little doubt we should have been attacked and no doubt massacred for they were at least 10 to one.   Shortly after we embarked in our boats which were waiting to shove off.  Oct 19th Saturday  wooding and watering as usual.  The Capt went ashore to see some of the princes of the land but was immediately ordered off.  The Natives very troublesome Capt. Jim (a grand villain) drew his spear to throw it at one of the crew who had accidentally splashed water on him and was only kept from doing it by the sight of my rifle which I immediately drew on him  he then turned it off with a laugh.  This was the same man who two years ago threatened to poison the river because the Capt of the John Adams drove him out of his boat.  We told them that we should sail the next day but as a great deal of trading was going on they believed the other way. which I think is the only thing that saved us from

an attack.  for by telling them we were going away they thought it was only a hoax to get their things from them cheaper.  They knew that the next day was a day of rest with Christians and remarked that sposee you go borde you cum back gin in two day for wan day yu pray next day yu cum ketchee de wood and ketchee de water.  They all appeared very desirous of getting razors for what purpose I can not concieve [sic] for the women want them as badly as the men and I only saw one man 
[bottom of page torn off]

and king asked who he was they said he makee me.  he makee yu  he makee de bullucks, he makee ebry-ting.  And when asked about Mahomet who and what he was, they said.  Sposee yu got Capt of Ship.  sposee yu got firs leften (Lieutenant) well Gode he Captin.  Mohamis firs leften.  Meaning that God was the first in heaven and that Mahomet was second.   The men and boys are all circumcised and when they bury the dead they always put their head to the East.  their spear Musket &c along

[bottom of page torn off]

lot of trinkets made of wood ivory &c slung around their necks these they called Mohamis. and considered a charm against all harm.  They also believe in sorcery and when told that we had three great Doctors on board they asked that they would not kill them by their conjuring.   A Doctor they hold in higher estimation than a Capt or Prince.  A Capt Amongst them is a sort of head man in a family and a Prince is the head man of a village.   Polygamy is very common amongst them.  in fact it is almost universal.  Prince Wille had 10 wives and King Rubar who lived about 20 miles in the interior had 30 wives  It is not to be wondered at that Polygamy is common amongst all savages for in a government which (like this) is purely patriarchal the More Children a man has the more powerful he is for his son can fight or work for him whilst for his daughters he always gets so much powder and so many bullocks, so that (like the Roman mother when asked for her riches showed her children) a Malagast is rich when he has many children.  The reverse takes place in a civilized country for the more children a man has

the poorer he is in purse.  The Malagsh language is a soft liquid language.  almost every word ends in a vowel and they appear to have no sound like H in their language.  Calling Ship, Sipy  sheep seepee &c.  Nearly always leaving out the h.  The following is the first 10 numbers. viz  Esse = one Rya = two Talo = three  Effee = four  Lima = five  Enne = six  Fitte = seven,  volo =  Eight  seva = nine  Folo  ten.   Ruin folo = twenty   Talofolo  thirty  Zato = one hundred.   Lina Zata 5 hundred.  arvarite one thousand.  zato arevarite one hundred thousand &c.  Radima who is now dead was once king of the island.  his sister is now queen.  She has a large city in the interior but she is not known in this part of the isle.  The old custom was that the kings sons were to be destroyed and that his sisters sons should be the heirs to the throne.  The reson[sic] of this was that the knig [sic] sisters  sons were known to have royal blod in them whilst the wife of the wing's son was dobtul [sic] for no one knew whether they were

sons of the king.  this speaks but little for the virtue of the Royal family.   All Mulatoe children are put to death. [outlined in text:  on the sea coast from their intercourse with whalers &c a great many mulatoe children are born but never to live.]
One of the head men Capt John Stout Came on board to see us and was afterwards employed in the boats as a pilot.  The Mids rigged him up up [sic] with shirt cap and pants. which made him as proud as could be.  When rigged up I got a small mirror with a Magnifying glass of great power on one side and plane looking glass on the other.  showing him the plane side first he viewed himself with great satisfaction but after some foolish mummery which he took for conjuring we showed him the other he put his hand to his head started back stared and with a loud ugh big doctor ran on deck and it was sometime before we could prevail on him to come down again.  he thought at first that his head was swelled and kept feeling it over and over sometimes saying  you no killee me. wille yu  Another came into the steerage whilst we were at

at supper.  we gave him a lump of cheese seeing some red pepper and noticing that the Mids used he asked for some.  Old D a big western Mid took a tablespoon full told him to open his mouth and immediately shoved it in.  the poor fellow spit and sputtered it out the water running out of his eyes and blowing occasionally like a porpoise the other natives nearly killed themselves laughing whilst he poor devil was nearly dead with pain and rage.

along the coast have American names.   There was Jim along Josey.  One Eyed Riley.  Lucy Long.  Kitty Clover.  Kentuck Sal. Black Betsy. Jim Bravah &c.   King Douglas who lived about 40 miles to the S'  Came up to see us he was a great warrior and was very rich. having 40 wives, 100 slaves and 100 bullocks.  he was quite dignified and was not such a beggar as other great men who called on us.  when any of h is subjects came near him they had to crawl on all fours.  he sold us a good many sheep for which he was paid in powder.  all the neighboring princes stood in great dread of him.  The sheep on Madagascar are about as large as they are in the States but have no wool only a short coarse hair like a dog or goat.  Their tails are considered the greatest delicacy.  some of them weighing as much as 20 lbs and of solid fat.   The Buffaloes are about as large as a common sized cow with a small hump between their shoulders.  otherwise like the cow they give very good milk which the natives boil with a kind of root giving it a mealy taste

The French at one time made a settlement on the island but the climate was so unhealthy that the most of them died in six months after their arrival and the survivors were attacked and slaughtered by the Natives to a man.  Since then no white man has been allowed to live and remain in the island.  the night dews are very heavy they commence falling about sunset and by Eight P.M. the decks look like there had been rain.  Many reports have been circulated about the Malagash being Cannibals.  this travellers deny but from the best information I could get viz from the kings and princes of the land the inhabitants of the interior to the N' & E' of St. Augustin Bay are cannibals.  Oct 14th 1844.  having got every thing on board that we wanted called all hands and unmoored ship.  As I had been kept very busy since our arrival the first lieut gave me permission to take one of my mess boys and go ashore to try and get something in the way of fresh grub.  So being Caterer of the Mess and Money not being of much use I turned to and cut up the Mess curtains

to trade with the Natives for fresh grub.  this caused a terrible growl in the mess on account of the [blot on page] pride of some two or three of the Mess.   I got a boat and started  up for the watering place with orders to bring down the wood cutters.  Got up without trouble found a great deal of discontent prevailing amongst the Natives succeeded in getting a few pumpkins which are a first rate thing to take to sea.  we got upwards of 60 pumpkins for the ships company and then ordered the men to get into their seats which they did but the boat was so crowded that the men had scarcely room to pull their oars.  We had 40 men in the boat besides the crew.  the rowlocks were only two or three inches above the gunwale.  Mr Strain the officer in command would have left half of them on shore but the natives had evinced such a quarrelsome spirit that it would have been risking to [sic] much.  The ebb tide was running out and when we shoved off several of the Natives followed us down the bank with their spears.  when clear of the banks or just inside of the bar we all saw what we had to go thro to get to the ship.  The sea breezes which had been blowing strong had raised a heavy swell which running

against the ebb tide caused it to break heavily on the bar.  At every stroke of the oars water came in over the bows.  we however cheered up double banked the oats and gave way with a will.  As luck would have it by good management and a smooth time of the sea we got over without accident for had it broke whilst we were on the bar but few would have lived to tell the tale.  We had not gone more than a ¼ of a mile farther before one of the ships boats came alongside of us and relieved us of a part of our load.  with the rest we got on board without difficulty.  Hoisted in the boats &c  At sunset all the Men and Officers had come off but the Naturalist and two servants.  We were all somewhat alarmed for his safety and at 8 PM fired a gun for him.  At 9 the Capt ordered a boat to go ashore and see if anything could be found or heard of him  the Men understand that an expedition was going ashore came aft in a body and volunteered their services.  the same happened with officers.   The boats went ashore and found the [?D'?] on the beach by a large fire.  Nothing having

happened to him except missing the sundown boat.   The next morning Oct 20th  got underway and stood to the [?] out of the harbour spoke HBM Brig Sappho on a cruise.  the Mozambique Channel is full of English [?crusers?] on the look out for slaves.  They condemn any vessel on the slightest suspicions.  the brig Unio which took the Concords men to Cape town was taken and condemned by the Cleopatra for having 3 slaves on board belonging to a passenger.  Oct 23'  experienced a strong current setting to the N'&E'  passed to the eastward of the island Juan D'Nova about 15 miles distant  This island is a small sandy isle about 40 feet above the level of the sea.  Turtles and beautiful sea shells abound on it.  Likewise large numbers of sea birds.  The seas in its neighbourhood are not well surveyd and are considered dangerous to navigators.  We passed over the shoals marked down in the the chart sounded with 200 faths but found no bottom.  Oct. 24th  weather very light. and the sun as hot as blazes for several days the weather continued the same  viz light during the daytime and moderate during the night.   Oct. 25th.

experienced a strong current setting to the S' & W'  made the land at daylight employed during the whole day beating up to the Anchorage.  The land is low alond [sic] the coast with a white sand beach and a heavy surf rolling upon it only a few hundred yards from the waters edge.  the shore is lined with coco nut groves.  At sunset  finding the wind hauling more ahead and a strong current sweep us to the S' came to off St jago isle which lies at the enterance [sic] to the harbour.  The last tack we made was within a half cables length of the breakers and whilst in stays the wind hauled and freshened up making it for some time doubtful whether she would miss stays or not had she missed these would have been great danger of going on the rocks over which the sea was breaking as high as our bulwarks.  The next morning Oct 29th [?] up between the two isles St Jago & St George which form the Southern enterance to the harbour of Mozambique.  The City of Mozambique is on an isle

about 1¼  Miles long.  Extending nearly North & South across the harbour.  it has one of the best harbours on the East Coast of Africa being a safe anchorage the heaviest kind of weather.   Mozambique was first settled by the Portugese about 400 years ago   Vasco De Gama a Portugese first stopped there and found it in possession of the Arabs who welcomed him with music but as soon as they found he was a Christian they treated him badly and finally attacked him but he soon reduced the place.  Since then it has remained in their possession.  On the north end of the island is a very large quadrangular fort. a proud monument of ancient Portugese industry.  it mounts about 60 guns most of them not fit for use.  it was commenced in 1537 and finished in 3 years.  on the south part of the isle is another fort. and on a shoal to the westward is another.  The Portugese part of the City is very well built and laid out in a regular manner.  many of the houses would do credit to any city but they are all old.  and have the marks of several centuries upon them  in every street grass grows on the side walks

and goats may be seen grazing in almost every corner.  in passing tho [sic] the town some dozens of times I never saw one white man except those who belonged to our ship.  The Governors house is a well built house fronting to the west with a flight of winding stairs (stone) from the inside court to the second story.  it is furnished something between the comfort of Europe and the luxury of the East.  in the Portugese part of the town there are several large public squares.  some of them with monuments and what once was fountains but even these were suffered to go to ruin.  the fountains had either caved in or had been broken off and the monuments were so covered with dirt grass and moss that it was difficult to tell whether they were or were not a vegetable production.  in front of the Custom house is a [?] stone wharf built out something like a 1/4 of a mile into the Sea.  it is built on arches and no doubt was once a beautiful structure but like every thing else it has been suffed [sic] to drop piece by piece until but little of it

stands and that so frail that a few years more will bring it down.  Every thing in Mozambique seems to go on in a sort of careless way the very walk of the banyans and Arabs seems to say what matter the city will perish before many years and nothing but a few bamboo [?] will mark the place of the once rich and powerful City of Mozambique.  Many years ago that is 30 or 40 years there was a considerable slave trade from this place. and about 100 years ago 10,000 slaves were annually exported to other parts of the world.  besides this gold dust and Ivory was brought in in such quantities that the only thing which was wanted was ships to carry it away.  during that time Mozambique harbour was crowded with ships and fair women were seen looking thro the dark windows where now only an old negroe hag or a mulato wench can be seen thrusting their wooley heads out, but bad laws and bad mannagement [sic] will ruin any country  so it has been with this.   We found the Govenor [sic] a fine gentlemany old man who had been educated in England and had served thro the whole of the Peninsular war.  he spoke English very well and treated us very kindly.  how deep an impression

a little kind treatment will make on the heart of a stranger a kind word spoken or a hearty shake of the hand will sometimes make a friend of a man for life.   The Negroe part of Mozambique is on the south part of the island and built without regularity and forms a strange contrast with well built houses of the Portugese.  their huts are built of bamboo canes thached [sic] with palm leaves  they build the fire to cook by either in the middle of the floor or just out side of the door.  to enter one you have either to go in on all fours or stoop your head as low as you can  should these catch on fire it is like so much powder.  Nothing can stop the flames.   The Markets are very poor indeed  being an open common with a long low bamboo shed too low to stand under.  on the ground in the vicinity numbers of negroes are squated [sic] with an old basket or a wooden tray some times with a handful of tomatoes or 5 or six eggs.  another with one or two bunches of bannanaas. and another with two chickens all carrying on a small picayune trade so that a man

wishing to buy a dozen eggs would have to go to two or three trades-men.  As I wanted a good deal of fresh grub for our Mess (so did Mr. Dale want grub for the Ward room) we bought every thing we could find in the market, costing us about $8 for which we got 5 or 6 dozen chickens.  As Many dozen eggs. and a few Tomattoes [sic] it being the dry season could not find many vegetables  the sea shores are covered with beautiful shells which would ornament any mantle yet from being common they are not viewed in as pretty.  I bought a beautiful leopard skin for about 25 cts. and saw several others from all that I could learn Leopards tigers lions Elephants hyenas &c were as thick as [?] on the main land.  The Portugese influence does not extend more that [sic] 30 miles from the fort and that influence very imperfect.  to tell the truth I do not think they have any sway out of gun shot of the fort.  The fort has about 2 hundred soldiers   Most of them black  the whole white population can not exceed 3 hundred and these are either convicts or the Governors[?suit?]  The Arab and Banyan population is considerable the [sic] carry on all the Commercial business and are the

moneyed men of the place.  The Banyans are Natives of Hindoostan and worship a cow as their god. Their dress is very much like the Arabs having loose flowing robes and trousers  generally white their head dress is usually a large red handchf passed loosely around the head with a small cows horn in front around which the red hkf is neatly passed.   they resemble very much a cocked hat with a high peak in front.  They are a very mild and peacable [sic] set of men and in  every port from Canton to Cape of Good Hope where a penny can be turned there will you find a Banyan.  The boat that boarded us was manned by Negroes.  Most of them had their hair shaved close off being Mohometans [sic]  The officers were Arabs having Portugese Commissions.  I visited the Mosques as well as the Catholic Church.  The former I found to be an old building with nothing but the bare walls and a few straw mats on the floor.  At 12 M at sun rise and at sunset and at Midnight the priest mounts the top of the mosque and calls the inhabitants to worship.  At the East end of the building on a small stand stood a well thumbed Koran the Mohometans are very strict in their

forms of religion and are strictly upright and honest amongst themselves.  The laws of the Koran are followed to the letter and but few are found who do not pray wash and fast as often as the Book orders.  For a Christian to enter a Mosque is either death or else to turn Mohometan.  And be circumsized.  this is the old law but it [crossed out: has become] is now only known as one of the old customs of better times and better countries.   Tho in Arabia. Turkey. Persia &c it is still enforced. whilst here one can escape by giving a small present to the head priest who finds it more to his benefit to cut your purse than to cut your throat..   The tide rises about  12 feet and runs quite rapidly.  One of our boats that had been left some 20 or 30 yds from the water was soon high and dry out of water [crossed out: but] we had but little trouble in launching her as some 50 or 60 Negroes volunteered and we soon ran her off into deep water.  Whilst on shore I saw a regular knock down between two darkeys.  a police officer was a few hundred yards off he moved in a slow walk to the place of combat and the two darks took to their heels.  I mentioned that I did not see a single white man but remember

having seen one looking thro the bars of a window upon enquiry I found that the said window was a window of the Calaboose or jail.  Their money is mostly gold and silver of the same denominations as used in Portugal.  their small change are coppers.  A little larger than a cent and valued at about 16 to the dollar.  There are a great many different kinds of beautiful wood on this coast many of which are exported to Europe.  The Coco nut groves are almost without end. and the coco nuts are the principal food of the Natives.  They make a sort of drink which they appear to be very fond of from the coco nut milk.   Oct 28th  got underway and went to sea.  weather very pleasant winds light  Oct 30th  saw a large water spout the first we have seen during the cruise.   Oct  31st  saw another large water spout  sounded in 25 faths. kept the hand lead going getting from 13 to 20 faths  bottom coral white sand and black sand alternately  At 10 PM found the water shoaling came to with the kedge in 7 faths water.   The land in sight under our lee.  in the Morning at Daylight got up the kedge and made sail.   the water on these

50
shoals is very clear for I was able to see the bottom in 7 & 8 faths water.  Novr. 1st  standing along the land.  The land is of a moderate highth resembling very much the hills near and around St Augustine bay.  with a white sand beach.  About 4 PM stood in to the mouth of Bimbalooka bay which is a large bay extending 20 or 30 miles in the interior having an enterance [sic] of about 8 miles wide.  being quite deep and free of dangers.  stood in and came to in 7 faths of water.  in standing in for the harbour we observed a large white flag flying on a hill to the Northward and as we opened the NE point viz Ft Mazunga  we were surprised at the sight of some half dozen well built stone houses neatly white washed. and on a distant hill to see a round fort with high weapons glittering on the rampart.  on going into harbour I am stationed in the Man top and taking advantage of this stole up on the topsail yard from whence I could view the whole bay.  soon after I seated myself on the Yard.  Some half dozen or so Men Came up I was so interested with the scene that I did not notice them until I was hailed from deck by a voice whose clear scream (if I may call it so) every one

recognized saying Mr Buckner are you going to establish a colony up there.  this was sufficient so driving all hands down and jumping on a back stay slid it down in the top.  in short order, soon after furling sails a large boat with some 8 or 10 Negroes was seen coming down to the ship.  After one or two unsuccessful attempts to get on board they at length succeeded and we were boarded by two officers both in American uniforms followed by some 6 or 8 darkeys with nothing but a loose shawl or robe thrown over their left shoulder and extending down gracefully to the knees leaving the right arm entirely free in the right hand they each carried a bright spear with a clean well polished wood handle made from Some of the Native wood.  some of which is beautiful.  We found A M Marks an American residing here collecting hides for a firm in Salem Mass.  he had been out here four years and had been trading up and down the coast for 15  he spoke the language like a Native he told us that they (the firm) did not find it so profitable as it once was during the time of King Radama, that during his reign they could cure & send off ship load after ship

ship load which cost them almost nothing except the trouble of stowing and taking care of them after they were stowed  The town of Majunga is situated on the NE pt of Bombatooka bay near a low sandy point at the foot of a small hill.  it very irregularly built mostly of bamboo thatched with palm leaves.  There are some half dozen stone houses built by the Arabs and Americans they are all neatly white washed tho badly built (The Americans give about one dollar in goods for hides they are not allowed to buy beeswax &c as formally this king monopolized by the Queen and the governors of the different provinces)  There is only one regular street running thro the town and this runs near the waters edge another street runs up to the fort which street is wide and open.  The town is built on the sand and the sun being directly over head made the heat almost insuportable.  so much so that even the natives complained of it.  several of the officers of the garrison are good looking men and two of them spoke English very well whilst another wrote a beautiful hand.  Every thing has a price set upon it by the governor and any one selling under this price is liable to imprisonment

and punishment by flogging.  Stealing is very severely punished by imprisonment and Slavery.  A few months before we came in a native was put to death for stealing and setting the town on fire.   There is several large dows hauled up on the beach built by the Arabs now wrecks but at one time quite substantial vessels.  There is now building a quite good looking dow. by a Native carpenter.  They (the natives) are a very ingenious people weaving beautiful mats of the inner bark of a tree also beautiful bands showing a great variety of colors in regular order and perfumed with a very pleasant odor  As the dry season has just about closing all the Natives are busy rethatching their houses.  The ground is so dry and parched that scarcely a spring of grass can be seen (there has not been rain here for 3 or 4 months) and even the coco nut trees begin to look a sickly yellow for want of moisture.  The Coco nut trees near and around this place are almost inumerable  How Wonderful is gods wisdom to behold for here in this parching heat amongst the burning sands a weary traveller or labourer can find a pleasant beverage and a cool refreshing drink from the coco nut

Honesty amongst these people is almost a general thing  Their houses are so slightly constructed that it would be but a small job to break in and rob them of their contents.  A lock is not however considered superfluous for I observed several with padlocks on them but something like a mail bag which an Indian saw he observed that his knife laughed at it.  And it is the same way with these houses for it easier to pull down the able end than walk thro the open door.  there are many different tribes or casts in Madagascar all at war with each other.  the two principal however are to [?Ovahe?] tribe and the Sacalava tribe.   The Ovar tribe occupy the north end of the island and also the east side. from Port Dauphin to Cape Amber whilst the sacalava own the remainder.  The Capital of the Ovah kingdom is Tananarivo situated [?nealy?] south east of Rembatooka.  it is said to be a large well built city having 7 large market places.  Since Radama's death his Queen Radavallo Manzata has reigned as soon as Radama had kicked his last the Queen ordered that all of his relations and friends should be put to death accordingly near 8,000 persons were executed in different parts

of the island. She has a large body guard, who continually keep near her person. When her meals are brought to her every one must clear the track as they are very suspicious for fear the queen might be poisoned. She is never allowed to walk  but when she goes abroad she has slaves  to carry her, for fear the fatash Men or Priest shall poison the ground and there by kill the Queen. There are many good workmen & in the city and whilst at chajunga I saw several with printed Dictionaries of the English and Malagasky language printed in (Tamanarivo?) (it is a remarkable circumstance that every word ends in a vowel and that they have no words of one syllable) it is a soft and melodious language and apparently a pretty one. Majunga is the north point of the Bay of Bembatooka and is a low sandy point whilst just back is a high hill on which the governors house is built. The town of the same name is the largest in the Bay. Nearly south of Majunga is the city of Bembatooka only not so large. Neither of them being overgrown. The Governor came on board to see the ship he was rather an ill looking man. Not as fine looking as his aids who accompanied him

of them are frequently seen prowling around and near Majunga for the offals of bullock &c that are killed for their hides  they are not a ferocious as the wolves of America and are seldom ever known to attack a man.)  this low point was almost covered with human bones and our surgeon obtained several fine phrenological specimens from amongst the numbers that were laying in the sand.  And a Mid the Masters mate of the Grog tub got one and shoved it in his locker just over the spare grog and to open his door it was quite a curious sight to see a pot of grog and a deaths head.   Tho I dare say it was the best picture that could be drawn of grog for it said as much as this viz Drink and die.  of all the curses put on earth Grog is one of the worst I scarcely ever new [sic] a man to get flogged but that grog was at the bottom of the matter.  I never knew a sailor to get drunk but that he wished to fight his best friends and when duty was carrying  on for a little grog to get amongst the men was to stop the duty and get themselves and the officer in charge in trouble.   This I saw strikingly exemplified in Majunga for there there was only one beaker of liquor in the whole

place but a sailor smells grog as far as a buzzard does carrion and as a matter of course they found it and got drunk.  previous to this the boats crews were allowed to go where they pleased but afterwards they were not allowed to leave the boat without an officer attending them.  Nearly all the Cooks of the Messes were allowed to go ashore to buy any thing they could in the way of provisions.  They got drunk as usual and when signal was made for all hands to come on board they paid no attention to it.  It however happened that the Capt was ashore and soon as he saw how matters were he fell to with his walking stick and made them move it was a laughable sight to see our old Capt with his silver locks streaming in the air sometimes with out a hat, chasing a lot of drunken fellows in the boats.   He went into one house in which a big marine and three or four sailors were enjoying themselves as soon as they saw the old fellow they did not stop to go out of the door but rushed tho [sic] the gable end. carrying away the whole side and part of the roof the Capt followed giveing [sic] every one a crack that he could catch he finally succeeded in getting them

all off to the ship.  the next day he gave them a dozen for getting drunk &c   There is one amusing chap on board a Baltimore negroe who belongs to the Forecastle.  Who has seen all the ups and downs of a sailor life having commenced his sailors life during the last war.  served at the battle of Baltimore and then in a Privateer and from thence in other ships having been in every thing from a whaler to a slaver inclusive serving in almost every service under the sun and speaking a dozen different languages besides which he had a great fund of wit and humor which made him a general favorite both amongst the Men and officers.  He belonged to the watering party and was the only man on board who had ever been to this place before.  he told that he was here in a Bati'mon craft for jerked beef and that she laid here 6 months during which time she lost 3 of her crew. and at the end of the 5th month the Capt said well boys I let us leave this place but at the same time added I should like to stop here all the days of my life  Sure enough said the old Negro he did stop here all the days of his life for the next day he died and said he pointing to a sandy point on the south shore if you go over thar {sic] you can see  his grave for we buried him there.

November
and covered the grave with some boards. which you can see if the natives have not carried them away.  Our second mate said a prayer and we all said Amen for he was a good skipper and knowed how to sail that craft.   he could speak the Malagsh very well and used to give us good grub and gave us plenty of liberty so god bless him.   We kept a look out on his grave for some time for fear the natives would dig him up for his clothes.  The Capt went up to the fort to pay the governor a visit and to my surprise was saluted with 9 guns.  The next day we sailed being the 4th.  Stood to the N' experienced a succession of light airs and calms.  Novr 7th made the land stood in for it and at 4 PM came to off Nos Bek, in Passendova bay.  Nos Bek is a small island off the North west coast of Madagascar and is extremely fertile.   it is a French settlement and has been in their possession for about [crossed out:  more than] 10 years.   There is a french guard ship laying off the village and several French families once lived at the village but all have died.   There is now about 50 convicts living ashore on different parts of the island.  The island is beautifuly [sic] rolling and

produces any thing that the climate will admit of  there are nearly [?500?] inhabitants in the village which like every village we have yet visited is built of bamboo & thatched with palm leaves  there is however several good houses built by the Frenchmen.  The French have raised a flag staff in the middle of the Village   directly south of the village is a small island known as nine pin isle and directly south of this is Passendow a village.  The Natives of this part of the island are similar in looks manners and Customs they are all Mohometans and those who do not acknowledge the French acknowledge the Queen or king who lives at Tamanarivo.  I have said in several parts of my letter that the natives were all Mohometans this is a mistake for there are many who have no religion at all and have no more idea of a god than a hog has of holliday [sic].  Then there are others who worship idols, birds, fish, alligators &c.   The Queen of he isle is said to have no religion.  Several years ago there was a great many missionaries in the isle but because they intefeared [sic] with the government and with the other religions of the isle

which instead of minding their own business and preaching the Gospel they turned to and abused as damnable herisies [sic] &c   They were all ordered to quit the island and every one was commanded to renounce the Christian religion and curse it.   Those who would not were instantly put to death.  Many hundreds were put to death and only 2 weeks before our arrival the brother of the Queens secretary was caught praying to God using a Christian prayer book   he was immediately seized confined condemned and executed his body was then cut up into small pieces and sent to the govenors of each province as an example of what would be done to them should they be caught praying to the Unknown God.   for the Christians God is unknown in Madagascar.  Whilst at Bembatooka I heard thro M' Marks that at the village some months ago there was an execution the circumstances were these viz that the Govenor had some 7 or 8000 troops he being then at war with the Sacalavas who inhabit the other side of the bay.   The Watering place was outside of the fort and the Govenor made a practice of sending an escort of 20 men to get water the Sacalava indian like waylaid the well or spring and attacked

those who were sent so one morning the govenor or general sent a party of men to get water.  They were attacked and after fighting for some time they retreated leaving 10 men dead on the ground.  The Govenor sent for those men who had escaped he immediately asked them where are the other 10 men.  they said they were dead.  Then said he why did you not stay and get killed too. and fight to the last as an Ovah and a Warrior should.  The answer was that the [crossed out:  number of the] Sacalava were too maney [sic] for 10 men to fight that would be foolish for a 10 men to fight a hundred.  The Govenor gave them no answer but ordering a guard confined them and order that the next morning they should suffer a cowards death viz to be burned at the stake which was done.   Many other instances of cruelty could be Mentioned but the above is enough)  The same laws that govern the Malegash at Majunga and Bimbatooka governs them here and a Malegash in saying his prayers if he does not pray to the Mohometan God with his face to the East he must pray with his face to the SE viz towards the queen whom he blesses in every prayer  on the island of Nos bek is a beautiful watering place from which

we obtained upwards of  5000 gallons daily  the Water is perfectly pure in taste.  [crossed out:  the water]  it runs off off [sic] the Mountain in a bold stream.  The scenery is remarkably wild and beautiful.Tall clustering trees with white paper like bodies and large spreading tops the curious and beautiful undergrowth with wild rugged rocks tend to make this one of the prettiest places in Madagascar.   The French have shown a great deal of judgment in choosing this place for a settlement for notwithstanding the unhealthyness of the place a settlement would thrive if once properly planted.   The French are now looked on by the natives with out fear but rather with contempt. and the Government of Ovah have not even taken notice of them further than selling them this island. and one or two other isle near the coast in other parts of the island.   This was foolish policy in the Ovah Government for any European power getting a foot hold in Madagascar would soon subdue the island.  The natives of the south and SW part of the isle seem to have better ideas of things for no sooner had the French settled down before they were attacked and Massacred  to a man.  it would be better for the Malagash if they would do the same in the north part of the Island  Tho I hope they will not for I wish the French may take the whole Island

Many of the Natives have their hair shaved close off to their heads looking like a hair had never grown on them  being as smooth as the palm of a Mans hand or to use a sailors expression who upon seeing one of them shave so close that he could not see that hair had ever grown on his head Remarked that he (the Negroe) was no doubt his mamy & dadys favourite child and that they had wore all the hair off of his head patting him on it.  The reason of their shaving is that it is customary to mourn for the death of a relative after this manner  Many of them file their teeth to points looking like saw teeth giving them a very savage and ferocious look.   Tho there are more with their teeth perfectly black this they cause by chewing a kind of root which almost immediately turns their teeth a jet-black color.   Others have rows of pimples running down from their foreheads to the tips of their noses and other rows of pimples crossing under and over the eyes each of the pimples or bumps are nearly as large as a bean and are made by gashing the flesh and afterwards squeezing the parts together this is continued until a bump large enough is raised.  I saw one with these bumps all over his heart and arms and legs.  Tattooing is likewise practised how it is done I am not aware but they render themselves truly hideous.  others again collect the hair in lumps or balls shaving

off all between these balls.  These balls or knots they keep well greased with palm or coconut oil giving out a very offensive odour.   We found several Arabs here who were the business men of the place..  Like they were in every place we have been yet.  they are a great set of cheats offering to change money & with the obvious intention of cheating.  Whilst we were laying in this place Our old companion the French Jack Ass Frigate which saild [sic] from Teneriffe with us and after wards laid in Company with us at Rio.  She stood into the harbour understudding sails.  she then ran down into Fassendavu bay where she anchored Novr. 10th  several of the French officers came on board.   They say that the Bercan will remain on this station for 2 years.  A great Many of the Natives are sick at the village this is about the close of their sickly season.  The dry season is the unhealthy one for as soon as the rainy season commences, the sea breezes blow strong from the sea whilst during the dry season the winds blow from off the land and is unhealthy.  There are a great many different kinds of reptiles on the land some of them dangerous amongst them is a species

of anaconda.  The Chameleon is also very common I caught one and have him now in a box I dont know wheather [sic] I will be able to keep him but hope so as it is a curious animal having the body of a lizard a head shaped like a hood which he some times expands and eyes projecting out of his head so that he can look fore and aft and one of the most singular parts of it is he can slue one foreward and another aft or can slue one up and the other down.   It sometimes changes its color 3 or 4 times in a minute.  sometimes green and at others red then brown and then a sort of dirt-color.  There is a species of wild cats in the woods which keep up a terrable [sic] noise or a night they are quite harmless [?howeres?] but from some accounts of the Men it would be dangerous to trust one self ashore after night.  one of them a good simlpe hearted fellow a great swearer and as ignorant as be-damned came to me to tell me of the noises he had heared and the sights he had seen one moon light night from the head.  we were laying about 1/4 of a mile off shore when it appears that the above mentioned man went forward and said he M' [?Bucher?]

13th sailed from Nos Bay.  Arrived in Zanzibar Novr 18th
I have been to the Rocky Mountains but such screeching and howling I never heard before.  first said he these would come a howl then a scream and then a thousand other noises  equally as horrible.  And he finally concluded by saying he he [sic] had as cut his throat as to sleep one night ashore if I hadnt said then May I be billy be d....ned.  This Morning I as usual sent the Steward to Market he could only find a few potatoes and two bottles of Milk this was the first milk we had drank in our coffee or any other way since leaving Rio and we blowed it out strong     one Mid actually drank 6 cups and then called for more.  After filling with wood and water for there was nothing else to be had except a few Madagascar buffaloes.  We sailed Novr 13th after a quick and pleasant passage arrived at Zanzibar we boarded a Dow outside and sent a letter in to the American Consul to send us out a pilot but he did not receive the letter till we had gotten in.  we stood in between the isles of Pemba and Zanzibar and without trouble anchored off the palace of the Sultan of Arabia (Mtong).  Zanzibar is a low isle covered with verdure of all kinds and near the sea coast with tall forests of coco trees whilst in the interior are beautiful groves of orange and mangrove trees mixed with bannanas and a curious tho pretty kind of palm.  The hills are very regular and beautiful and are almost entirely coverd [sic] with fields of cloves and spice mixed with waving fields of rice Maze and sugar cane, but this is not all, cattle run wild and fat thro the groves and seem to want neither care or attention wild dogs rove thro the grave-yards and along the sea beach.   birds of prey hover over they [sic] towns  serpents cross our path lizzards and scorpions crawl on every bush and under every rock are found Tarantulas and centipedes.  in short every thing teems with life and Motion.   in the evening the incessent

[?Twin?] of the hungry Musquito.  annoy the weary traveler and at night the bright flashes of the fire flies still tells that even the air is full of animation,  every spot of ground, seems to produced [sic] something nothing can be seen but life animation and verdure on all sides,  and still  these gifts of nature are abused,   On the Morning after our arrival went on shore to water ship, also made up a party to visit the sultan of Muscat, whose palace was near the ship.  The old man met us out side of the palace at the gate and shook hands with  us after the custom of the Arabs.  we found his guards ready to receive us with the usual honors.  passing thro his front yard and tho [sic] a large hall we found ourselves in his audience chamber,  After conversing with the Sultan tho [sic] an interpreter, he treated us with coffe {sic] and the famous sherbit which we read of in the Arabian Nights.  the audience chamber was a rough stone hall with marble pavements rough chairs and a few english engravings hanging around the room  there was large niches in the walls which a kentucky Negro would think were intended to put closets or cupboards up in.  He kindly invited us to come and dine with him the next day  we accepted the invitation (The palace is a rough the substantial building built entirely of stone)   The Sultan is a man of about 50 to[sic] he looks nearer 80 (he has 80 wives or concubines.  I suppose this is what makes him look so old.)  Near the palace is a large dow building  by the sultans order.  She is composed of Teak wood which is as lasting as live oak.  on landing the second time opposite the sultans palace I found the windows crowded with curious gazers.  curious to see the Americans.   they were the Sultans wives some of them quite pretty for they graciously unmasked themselves that we might see them.  tho it was at the distance of a 3 story window iron bound and barred, the Mid struck the natives with Amazement and fright when taking off our hats we made several polite bows to the fair prisoners, for a native to have done this would have been death or imprisonment.  I have called them fair but, they were of all colors, white black red-copper yellow-tan - yellow-orange, and I expect a dozen others different shades and colors    back of the palace are beautiful groves of green Mangrove trees  Whilst a cool [crossed out: rushing] brook rolls its clear waters under their shades.  flower and roses are innumerable and thick luxurient grass green and pleasant to the eye and to the feet spreads on every side as a rich carpet

amongst the trees and shrubs could be seen number of little Negroes naked or nearly so gazing on us with a curious mixture of fear and curiosity which was laughable.   Around the spreading mango and amongst its thick limbs and leaves and over its rough bark twined green and graceful vines Many emitting a grateful perfume and giving to these noble trees a dark shady look which looks so refreshing even in a temperate climate but how much more so [crossed out: amongst] in a zone with the sun over head and its rays piercing thro' and thro' you.  Then the Cattle would look at us as strangers sniff the air  swing their tails and be off as the wild ones used to do in the Ouchita swamps of Arkansas.  At Mtony the sultan has a fine stud of horses   they are beautiful full blooded Arabs.  With arched  neck short ears and clean limbs.  Yet I have seen as pretty horses in the states but I do not think as clean limbed and as quick eyed.  During all this time we were kept busy.  and soon filled up with water, on the 21st A Number of us visited the sultan and dined with him.  he gave us a nice blow out.  giving in every thing but hog meat.  After filling up with water we hauled up off the town of Zanzibar which is about 3 miles to the S of Mtony  The Sultan is named Seid-Seid-Ben Sultan, he is the sultan of Muscat and has lived here about 8 years he having moved from Muscat in 36, his reasons for so doing was that the English were too near him, so that his government is as yet not in as good order as he could wish it.  his possession extend from Zanzibar to Mozambique to the S' and from Zanzibar to the mouth of the gulf of Persia to the Nd. an extent of coast as large as that of the United States.  his power does not extend far in the interior  his government is despotic but he is said to be a good and fatherly old Man to his people.  his Father was a rebel and an usurper.  he rebeled [sic] against the sultan of Mecca.  At his death his brother usurped the throne and sold Seid  the Sultans son was exiled, but he returned killed his uncle and put to death all opposers thus seated on his fathers throne, surrounded by Budoin [sic] Arabs of the Desert as guardsl  he was feared but not loved, so dismissing them, he became a kind and fatherly man to his people. but it did not long last.  he was too kind and the cities of Melinda and Mombas rebeled.  he sent his son to subdue them but after

8 years wasted he allowed himself to be surprised lost all of his ships all of his cannon and had 3000 Men cut to pieces, before his eyes.  with difficulty he escaped to Muscat.  his father raised an Army and in 18 months reduced the places to submission without any considerable loss afterwards he governed them with a More rigourous hand but still with Justice.  The Sultan has 8 or 10 Men-of-War several of which are now laying here  they are his own private property and in time of peace uses them as merchant men and carries on a brisk trade with Bombay and other English possessions.  one of them he sent to the States with a few presents to our President,  we met he [sic] Capt who was much pleased to see us as he had been well treated in the states.  The sultan capt Musslemen, slaves all dress alike and had I not been told would have thought the sultan was a slave or else nothing more than a common man at furthest.  The sultan had 3 sons.  the 2d' son is the govenor of the city of Zanzibar and is a complete petty tyrant.  he is lame from the [crossed out:  lepora leprosy] leperousy [sic] or in other words is a leper or one who can not leap.  his 3d son is still a child.  his 1st or eldest son is very popular. and is said to be a noble hearted fellow.  he is now in exile on account of some difficulty with his father.  The story is this.  his brother having just returned in disgrace from Melinda, his father raised a large army of Arabs of the desert, and left home to besiege Melinda and Mombas.  During the siege a circassian slave fair and beautiful without a blemish, was sent as a present to the Sultan.  The Eldest son seeing her fell in love with her and before his father returned Married her and she had a son.  The old sultan returned read his letters saw the beauty Modesty and grace of the young slave, he ordered his son to leave his dominions.  the next morning he sent a Messenger with money and offered him a frigate and the government of Muscat if he chose it  (the sultan was then as he now is living at Zanzibar.) but his son refused and he left and is now with his wife amongst [crossed out: the other wild] wild arabs of the desert who respect and love him as one of them.  When he left his 60 wives all ran out of the Harem and went to the sultan in a body and requested beged [sic] and prayed on their knees to let him stay, but the Sultan had ordered it and he was too obstinate and angry to undo one day that which he had done the day before tho it was wrong  And even the sultans young wives kicked up a rumpus [?] even under the sultans nose, sure he was a noble fellow for all the ladies loved him, we found several Men of war laying here  3 french and one English. and as this was more than had ever been seen here before it was a busy [crossed out :day] time with the Zanzibar folks.   The City of Zanzibar is on a low sandy point and at high water is surrounded with water.  it is on the w. side of the isle and is the healthiest place on this coast on the sea beach are several large stone houses some quite neat and pretty one of them is the Harem of the sultan son the other his palace the other the Custom house.   The other a house for the reception of the visits of strangers, the others are the houses of Rich Arabs and American

and English who are residing here.  all of whom drive on a brisk and profitable trade with the Natives for ivory Rice Gum. copal gold dust, Tortoise shell, cloves spice & curious and useful woods ebony. sandal. box & Dye stuffs  skins hides &c.  These things they buy up from the savages from the interior of Africa for blades bangles and dollars cloth cottons and knives &c.  Many of (these savage come down from their wild haunts and they are dressed in a curious and fantastic style some with heavy bangles on arms and legs weighing many pounds others with huge rings in their ears and noses and some again with brass and silver wire wove round & round their bodies and others again having all these trinkets and some again with tatooing and scarifying half moons and ridges over their faces across their noses and under their eyes, then others have their teeth sharpened to fit one in another like sharks.  some again big men and head men have all these charms.  one woman I observed with a large silver watch in each ear, a silver dollar [?brazed?] on a brass ring for a finger ring.  a large brass bangle one one arm and a silver on on the other.  with numerous trinkets around her neck and some few around her ankles to enumerate all their custom would be too numerous for this volume.)   There is an American and English and French consul here.  The Americans have cut out all others in trade and are the most business men of the place.   The English consul is a thick headed, head strong, hard drinking hard fighting good natured irish man once was a Capt in the English Army. and is now consul and political agent for the English East India Company.  he does no business except Consular but lives on his salary which is        [?15000$?] per year.  one of the most important personages of this place (besides a good hearted clever fellow & commodore) is Capt or Commodore Seid Hamet ben Hapen.  he is an old bachelor gets drunk when he chooses and is hospitable &c. talks plain and sensible speaks good english and is as polite as a dancing Master.  We called on him he has a neat comfortable and pretty house furnished both with an [?] to taste and comfort.  I called on him afterwards and found him a pleasant old fellow offered me wine and sherbet and other refreshments.  some months ago the old fellow had a knowing slave (he had 1000) who finding his master used to get fuddled stole money enough to buy his freedom, but, still continuing in his Masters service he told him that he had discovered a pot of Money containing 6 or 8000$ in a field belonging to Ben Hapen, and promised to show it for 100$.  this was given him but he told the old Capt that a spirit or devil or genie had moved it and said for more money he would show it to him so more money was given until old Ben Hapen began to get tired and the Rascal was obliged to give him some satisfaction so he led Ben Hapen to an old field and after digging they found a jar with a few pieces of rotten leather bags and 4 or 5 $ in the bottom.  the old fellow still believes that there was Money $6 or 8000 in the pot and that it had been removed by some genie or wicked or guardian spirit.  Back of the sultans palaces custom houses is the city  it is built of all kinds of materials.   bamboo and leaves[?logs?] coral and stones.  the streets are so narrow that it is difficult

for two men to walk abreast and they wind round and round.  the cross and crook turn and twine as it were full of dirt and mud and filth and big strong looking strong smelling Negroes.  it is no easy Matter to find ones way tho the town for we got lost amongst its windings.  There are several business streets the Bazar is one here are exposed for sale beads roots beans cloths cottons knives callicos silks &c  all the cotton goods I saw were marked Lowell Mills  in fact Most of the goods I saw were Yankee goods.  on the sides in the doors and windows were exposed these things for sale whilst back in a close room was the sleeping apartments.  The bazar that was some times crowded with Negroes [?] and loitering about.  Next the Market street was the most important  There was every thing to be seen that the isle produced in the way of eatables but usually in such small quantities that it was difficult to obtain enough for more than one person without going to a dozen.  Then came the private streets dirty and crooked but not as bad as the public ones.  in every street that I went the Natives looked at me with curious expressions and all seemed as friendly as could be.  The little negroe children seemed amused at me and when two or three of us were together we were followed like a Militia Company is in the states in every street we went there we found the Natives as kind and as polite as curious and inquisitive as Yankees, many poor devils asked me to step in and look at their sick brothers or sisters or fathers.  Many asked me for charms and I followed the example of Mongo Park who gave them the lords prayer,  in many streets I saw black smiths and was induced to stop to look at their work.  The black smith does all his work sitting down.  he has a little shaver who blows the bellows, does it also sitting down.  he blows it with two bags of leather open at top and fitted with two pieces of wood air tight which he opens as he draws it out with thumb and hands.  And shuts as he pushes it from him to keep the air in better pieces of soft hide or skins are fastened on the inside all their work is done sitting  there are also silver smiths on a small scale near the out skirts of the town are a kind of mills to grind the palm oil out of coco & palm trees  the mill was moved by Camels.  The palm oil is sent to America & Europe.  The Town contains about 30,000 inhabitants, Mostly Negroes who are slaves to the Arabs, Banyans, Parsees &c.  the Mosques are very numerous and are well built neat buildings one that I entered was extremely well furnished and clean and was full of worshipers it is the law of the Coran or Koran that an unbeliever entering a Mosque must either turn Mohometan or be put to death;  This is the law every where but in Madagascar and in Mozambique the law has changed this much that you can get off by paying a sum of money.  but here it is different for they are Arab and the Sultan is sei-seid Ben Sultan a true believer and defender of the faith.  Not knowing the custom I mounted the steps leading to the Mosque and entered the door.   There was several fellows on all fours bowed to the ground.  At first I thought they were fastening down the mats but then I saw them get up all facing the same way, bow and down again.   I had hardly time to see these things before I was caught by the arm by one of the Consuls friends who pulled me down off and away in short order I had hardly time to see the half drawn knives and angry glances of the Arabs before I was out of danger.  Capt Wilson gave me a severe lecture about it saying that there were many fanatics who would think it right & proper and that to kill me would please god and the prophet.  After I was more careful and kept a proper distance from them.  The Mohometan confession of faith is this Allah el Allah.  Mahome Ras-ul or god is great and Mahome is his prophet.  They pray 5 times per day and wash themselves (face and arms) there are two sects who are mortal enemies  they split on this [crossed out:  that is] viz. the place to commence washing at.  The followers of Ala' commence at their finger ends and wash the followers of Omer commence at their elbows.  Should two Mahometans meet says

a certain great traveller and shake hands and hail and bless each other in the name of the Prophet. and when the time of their meals and prayers arrive one should be observed to wash from his elbow and the other from his finger ends.  They are mortal enemies and are a ready to cut each others throats as they were before to defend each other.  There are some learned men amongst the Arabs that is they can read and write and understand the Motions of the planets.   They also have schools the teachers generally get about 10 cts per month from each child.   I saw one who was teaching two youngsters the Koran.  he appeared to know it by heart and read it off in a sort of song as fast as he could talk there is but few or in fact I believe none who can read the bible off the same way (from Memory) for page after page.   When I first saw the Koran I took it for a badly constructed music book.  the reason was the size and musick note like shape of the letters, and the tone and manner of sort o' half singing or chanting it out,  the Banyans or Hindoos are the next most numberous class they are the go ahead sort of people of asia and are great business men of the place.  being the Yankees of Asia.  they Worship a cow and have many strange and superstitious customs.  they believe in a great and universal being who is eternal.  that he made the World has three distinct shapes the above being has various passions and that he delights in assuming the shape of a Cow.  so they purify themselves with cow dung and urine and make gods of wood & copper which they offer sugar honey &c.  they think the the Brahems came from the head and that other mortals came from the more inferior parts of his body.  The Parsees are another sect.  They are also industrious people and are the Jews of Asia.   They have the same religion as the Christians and Jews.  in Their books with this difference.  that they have a Zooroaster as a prophet.  And they think that God is the sun and that his spirit is the flame of fire.  They have their feast of unleaven bread their confessions of sin &c.  but the common people worship fire and the sun without knowing their reference. and this religion once pretty and good is now a blind Idolatry or what is called.  A Parsee will not blow out a light with his breath on any account.  if his house catches on fire he lets it burn down.  Their books tell the same tale about the Creation of the World the fall of Man &c. besides these there are many who worship snakes, lizards, bits of wood, stone, smoke, bones &c.  there are no white men on the island except foreigners.  The Arabs are dark skinned fine featured but as dark as our indians.  The Banyans and Parsees are the same the Negroes are as black as the devils boots.  There was a story related to me here which if true is not more than might be expected.  An Arab man and woman had a child.  he was born and was as black as any Negro on the isle.  I saw the man myself he had been sent to England and was well educated and a smart intelligent fellow with a good deal of humor.  Now if the Arab woman who was a respectable one and of high birth was true to her lord does this not prove that the people of Africa have one day turned black.    Back of the town is the burying ground in fact part of the town is built over the burying ground,  it is very irregular and is full of bushes briars and young bamboo canes.  Wild dogs are as thick as hops in it and live and stay there to feed on the dead bodies of the slaves which are brought out but never buried.  I saw several dead Negroes during my stay one of them was on the sea beach.  They allways make it a custom never to bury slave but let dogs eat them or fish devour them.   There are no large wild animals on the isle except a few wild cats.  the woods are full of Gazelles which are beautiful animals and easily [?taken?}

There are several large Monuments in the grave yard, with Arab inscriptions on them.  Near the grave yard is a strait piece of road which the Natives use to run races on them near here also is the slave Market.   There are annually sold, in Zanzibar, upwards of 15,000 slaves.  They are all bought from Africa and are seldom or never fed till they find a master.  Many of them die with hunger and at most they never get more than a hand full of rice.   After they find a Master it is quite a different affair for then they are use by the laws of the Koran to eat when their Master does to eat what he does and the Master is obliged to furnish each slave with a new suit of clothes every time that he buys one himself.  in fact slavery amongst the Arabs is nothing more than serving amongst Christians.   A slave is allowed to speak his mind and works only when he feels like it.  this is the law but the law is not followed. Always and a slaves life then is truely miserable.  it also orders in the Koran that if a slave turn Mahometan he is free but this their master wont allow them to do.  there is a strong  bridge at the north end of the town over an arm of the sea it  is strong but rough.  On the sea Coast is a large square fort with high round towers at each corner.  it was built by the Portuguese in 1537. and no doubt was a strong fort. just in front of this fort is the water battery mounting 22 guns, some of them in good order.   This town and isle was first discovered by the Portuguese who found it inhabited by Negroes and Arabs.  The Portuguese took possession built the fort and flourished for a while but the cupidity averice cruelty and ignorance of human nature soon reduced the place to almost a place of desolation and they possessed authority no further than the range of their long guns.   In the city they established an inquisition which inspired dread they erected a cross and prostrated them selves before and the Mahometans and Savages took them for idolators, the wild negroes and arabs from Africa were afraid to come over for they were liable to be burned at the stake for being heathens.  so at length by the abuse of the laws of Heaven and earth and of all laws of nature humanity and justice and of even law written on in the heart of Man Zanzibar came but an empty possession thus it continued.  The Portuguese fed and fattened on the blood sweat and toil of the Arabs and Negroes till their name was a name of repoch [sic] and hatred as well as of fear and dread.  About 60 years ago the Sultan of Arabia at Mecca sent Ben Sultan the present sultan's father to Muscat to attend to some important business being ambitious and enterprising he soon amassed a large fortune.   The Sultan of Mecca after some time sent letters for him to return.  this he declined doing.  the Sultan of Mecca then sent troops to take him and put him to death but Ben Sultan knew a thing or two for he had by kind treatment presents &c gain the friendship of the Arabs of the desert who acknowledge no man but the prophet and their chiefs.  of these he raised an Army and defeated and took prisoners the greater part of those sent to take him.  The Sultan of Mecca then sent army after army but Ben Sultan defeated them all took all the sea port towns and declared himself Sultan of Arabia upon this the Sultan at Mecca sued for peace which was granted on his ceding all his territory from the mouth of Gulf of Persia to Mozambique inclusive and declairing Ben Sultan the sultan of Muscat  this was done  Ben Sultan then with his troops sailed for Zanzibar landed there

and ordered the Portuguese garrison to surrender this they refused upon which the sultan attacked the place on two sides at once. at first they were repelled for the Portuguese knew their fate if he succeeded the next day he again tried it on all sides.  it was a long well fought battle the Portuguese stood to their guns till the last.  the Musslemen had made scaling ladders of bamboo.  these they fixed on the walls but the Portuguese threw them down men and all, but the Arabs were soon up and at it again.  but now the Portuguese had began to grow weaker  Many of their guns could not be worked for want of Men and the Arabs growing more furious again attempted scaling.  this time tho gallantly opposed they succeeded the Portuguese were slaughtered like sheep, and few were spared to tell the tale.  The shot holes of this battle or siege can still be seen for the Arabs are to lazy to stop them up. and around the ramparts and embrazures where the guns were worked a Mans hand can not be laid without covering up a shot hole of some kind.   Ben Suntan was well paid for his trouble for he found an immense treasure of gold dust and ivory which they hd collected to send home.  He was on the point of sending an expedition agains Mozambique when he died.  his brother usurped the throne.  The rest is already known.  The laws in the Sultans empire or dominions are still in a primative [sic] state.  The law for Murder is to kill the Murderer with the same Wepon [sic] and in a simalar [sic] Manner stealing is punished with imprisonment or flogging or death, Virtue is very uncommon amongst the Women, so their husbands keep them locked up and never allow them to go out without their veils.  Some of the Arab women are quite pretty, tho dark but not near as dark as the men  some of them were kind enough to unmask themselves to us poor devils of Americans.  it was quite a treat for none of us had even seen a pretty woman since leaving Rio and those at Rio were none of the prettiest.   The Men wear either long swords some of them double handed or else with a crooked keen knife which would have been a dangerous wepon [sic] in close combat.  Some of them we found to be great rascals.  There was one who called him self Rajab  he was a long tall fellow quite handsome and very intelligent  he had been to America in a ship which was bound to Boston.  he was delighted with every thing he saw.  his description of the steam Boats and Rail Cars were laughable,   I asked him if he saw steam boats  oh yes.  me see go like hell big smoke wheel go round so fast make big noise no wind ah think he devil.  Me see rail Road too.  him burn like devil. go like hell.  No horse go faster horse Arab man on horse no catch him.  Me get on one me loose my turban when no stop go quick [?cum?] fast.  American man no make me pay.  go to New York big town fine city pretty ladies no got de veil on. (then lowering his voice he whispered so that the other Arabs could not hear him) heap prettier than any sultans wives.  Yes streets full streets broad like river all full folks horses. carriages. ebery ting.  More in one house dare than in all Zanzibar.  I come back tell fader me.  he take stick beat my head for lie.  say boat cant go without sail.  wagon no go without camel or horse or bull.   I tell every body.  every body tell me that I tell lies.  yes, say I lie, this fellow understood something of the laws of trade so he went around and tried to buy up all the fruit and vegetable chickens &c for sale to raise the

price and bring him money.   The young prince hearing of his sent out his slaves and beat Rajab for doing what every smart merchant does in civilized countries.  viz  Monopolized the saleable articles.  Such things as yams, potatoes, fowls, oranges &c are very plenty and cheap  Irish Potatoes will not thrive here but soon run into sweet potatoes.  Camels are not very numerous but are quite common.  If I was able I would introduce the Camel into the United States for they would be of immense use on the great western praries.  And no doubt will one day or other be brought over. tho. the states may be to [sic] cold yet the high lands of Mexico California &c are not. and these will no doubt be inhabited by English or American highlanders or Arabs whose hand will be against every man and every mans hand against them.  then if camels will live in the lat of     34. to 58º N. they will be of immense use to transport goods across the country from the Atlantic to the Pacific or the reverse.  The celebrated Mocha whence comes the Mocha Coffee belongs to this sultan tis said to be the hotest [sic] place in the world (except Muscat) for the winds blow directly from off the hot heated desert. here, even the winds from the W are hot and sultry and scarcely fit to breathe.  There it is much worse, this harbour is chock full of sharks and they form the principal food of the natives.  An American ship came in from Boston.  she was out on a trading voyage  She met with a great deal of opposition here from the Yankee traders who fear interlopers:  I never saw such fierce opposition before in the way of trade.  there was a total eclipse of the Moon on the 24th.  I never saw a prettier sight in my life.   The Natives were all very much frightened and kept up an incessant drumming all night howling dancing and singing beating on drums tin pans and boards making a most infernal clatter to scare away the big devil that was going to swallow the Moon.   I had told several men a day or so previous about the eclipse they only laughed at me and asked me how I knowed.  when they saw me again they pulled off their head covers to me as a great man.  I notice a curious snail that was very common here it was sometimes as large as a mans fist and one I think was twice as large  during our stay the sultan made a practice of sending us off a present of fruit and vegetables and before we sailed he sent us off a present of a goat.  each mess in the ship  The consul gave us a dinner party before we sailed and was very kind to us during our stay.  On the 27th November sailed the french corvette also sailed we took the consul with us as far as a small isle in the harbour where finding wind and tide ahead came to anchor.  When the consul left the ship our band struck up home Sweet home.  it was a strange sight and filled us all with peculiar and strange thoughts of home.  then to see these Adventurous Yankees on the scorching and sickly coast of Africa pushing ahead and spreading the name and fame of the Yankee Nation to the heart of Africa.  There was two ignorant sailors who run off from the 1st Cutter whilst Watering the Capt offered a reward for them and they were brought down that night in irons the next day they were punished.  they both were taken sick with the African fever afterwards and came near dying.  A crew of an American Whaler ran off here also  they were three weeks on the isle and all died.  The night air and dews are nearly always fatal to strangers.  Our ship had been painted a lead color with a red streak as it is well known that black draws the heat and wishing to keep cool and healthy our ship was painted the above color.  This the Banyans, Parsees &c admired very much as it is the color which they paint their temples.
[Written in left margin]
Their are laying in front of the fort 6 or 8 guns long  [?] guns fifteen feet long they are about 300 years old and have[?] [?] inch in diameter they have Portuguese inscripition on them just over the Portuguese is an Arab inscription telling when how and [?] they were taken.

The winds being light & ahead we had to bat out which took us all day.
