A bright light is a good police.  I was in Canton on the 5th day of the 4th Moon or on the days which they celebrate the feast of the Great dragon or the god of the waters.   On this day all business was suspended  crackers rockets and guns kept up a continual rattle whilst the loud sounds of gongs could be heard over the whole town  In almost every street were theatres or the like dancers &c. On the Water was the prettiest sight.  long dragon boats from 80 to 120 feet long and some even 150 feet and only about 2 feet wide and painted and gilded in a splendid stile were pulling up and down the river.  one of them pulled 88 paddles  she went with great speed.  at each end and amidships were platforms on which were dancers [crossed out: and]  singers and juggler  They exercised their tricks &c with surprising dexterity and the dancers were in some instances quite graceful.  about every 15 feet in the boat were gongs on which men kept time with a stick or something of the kind, Each man kept time with a paddle and accompanied it with his voice.   there were 8 or 10 of them with thousand of pleasure or flower boats looking on, it was a beautiful sight,  In a large garden was spread out a feast of which any one partook who chose.  this garden was beautiful place vines were led in such a manner as to represent almost every thing.  Houses, Junks &c.  Whilst figures of Animals were made of porcelain with open mouths and shrubs growing therefrom. or an elephant with a hole in his back and a small tree growing out,  The Flower Boats are beautiful boats of pleasure.  They are splendidly carved gilded painted and ornamented.  They all are hired on these days of feast by wealthy Chinese who fill them with pretty Chinese girls.  I was invited into one of them by a Chinese gentleman

and treated to a cup of the best Suchong tea.  The girls all fled on our approach to a back room.  [?] English gentleman & I ventured to the back Room but on our approach they nearly all ran on to the top of the boat.  However a few of the shyest having hid behind curtains were surrounded by us two.  They were beautifully dressed in fine embroidered silks   the poor [crossed out:  devils] angels trembled violently whilst the Fan Gui's were looking at them.  All Chinese girls paint to excess their lips are as red as coral whilst their skins are whitened almost as white as snow with pearl powder.  their cheeks are tinged with crimson.  altogether I think there are some very pretty girls if not beautiful ones in Canton.  The town of Boats in Canton is a Curiosity in its self.  These are 80,000 boats in Canton river.   They are ranged in rows  streets are regularly made between them in these boats are shop of all kinds.  The laws of China will neither allow these river people to live on shore nor intermarry with those who do.  Tis said that the River or Boat town contains 800 000 inhabitants  when the English took Canton they landed above the town marched around the west side and occupied the high lands immediately in the rear of Canton.  There are some beautiful gargens [sic] near Canton with fountains artificial lakes &c. one of these lake which I saw was covered in a beautiful manner with the flowering lotus and was an enchanting sight, there are no factories of Porcelain in Canton but they have some very Intensive glass factories.   One of the curiosities near Canton is the rafts with their thousands ducks.  it is astonishing what a discipline there is amongst them they have all learned to feed themselves and obey a call almost as redily [sic] as a human being.   Many of the fishermen train hawks to fish for them   This is another thing that astonishes everyone  these hawks will fly off a mile or two take a fish and return immediately to their masters boat.  The European factories are above the town.  The houses in Canton are built of blue bricks and usually not more than one story high, the red clay of China burns blue,  In Canton are several large pagods some of them in fact all of them are 9 stories high this I believe refers to some religious ages.  The Jos houses in Canton are gaudily dress'd off and show such a quantity of finery and such curious workmanship that they are well worth visiting.  Canton River is only about ½ mile wide at Canton but it is a very long river and is quite deep.  The River Yantse Kiang or the son of the sea is a very large deep and wide river.  it is nearly as large as the Mississippi.

a few hundred miles above its mouth it takes the name of the Golden Sanded.  The great lake of Tong ting Hoo is the largest lake in China  it is in a mountainous country its waters are clear and limpid.  The Yantse Kiang runs tho it.  This lake is the Country of the Macoutse.  The Macoutse are an independent race in the interior of China.  Their country is Mountainous and is surrounded by fortifications.  They do not wear their hair like the tartars and Chinese that is half shaved off with a long tail from the back of the head but wear it long all over the head.  These people sometimes make war against the Emperor but he always makes out to buy them off.  It is usually said that the grand canal of China is 600 miles long but it is a mistake for a great part of what is usually called Canal is a banked up creek.  There is an annal [sic] tax to support this canal.   on the bank of this Canal where it joins the Yellow River is a splendid temple to the great Dragon King who is considered the father of the waters.  there is a city near Peking called Hoagn for the Canal is above this City so that one on the Canal can look down on the top of their houses.  The Chinese have traditions of a deluge but they only say that it impeded agriculture and that it took place about 4000 years ago.  about 200 years before Christ the Emperor of China in order to keep out the Tartars erected the Great Wall, it is a stupendous piece of work, the wall is built of blue bricks and is 25 high & 20 feet thick.  Extending about 1200 or 1500 miles.   The City of Peking is in a low sandy plain the Emperor are near Peking but are now in a delapidated state tho they still possess much of their former beauty.  Hang Chow is the real silk city of China.  Hoc Chow foo is the tea City.  The Bohea hills from whence the Bohea tea is bought is near them And the fancy like lake of Syhoo covered with inumerable numbers of boats of pleasure & business lies between them.  In the Western part of China can be obtained the cow of Thibet or yak  From its tail is manufactured beautiful shawls and carpets.  A sort of [?inflamable?] matter is also found in the West of China which the Chinese use to burn in their lamps and call stone oil.  In some parts of China they use tea as a medium of exchange   The Emperor once per year ploughs a field and sows it he is called by his subjects the divine husbandman.  he is also called the ten thousand years, the Celestial father &c.  A great many years ago Him Ming a Chinese Emperor was attacked by the Rebels.  he retreated to Peking shut himself up and his Cause getting hopeless he stabed [sic] his daughter and cut his throat the same day this happened in the year 1643 this was the last of the Mongol dinasty of Ming. great philosophers had agreed that the seat of the human mind is the stomach.  All young men should endeavour to appear decent therefore they should keep clean and always have their shoes well whitened.   When you are invited to a feast always show your polite breeding and your relish to the fare by belching (breaking wind) &c at the table for doing these things shows that you have overloaded the stomach or in other words that your relish the dinner so much that you have [crossed out:  overloaded the stomach] eaten too much.   In general a chinese is the reverse of a European they sail their boats [crossed out:  backwards]  small end first read their books backwards and up and down instead of parallel to the top of the page.  They whiten their shoes wear their stockings and shirts out side of their trousers build their forts backwards as it were.  reckon the variation from the south instead of the north consequently when we say the needle has Eastly var. they say it has westly var. &c.  The women have a sort of thimble on their thumbs made of leather and shove the needle thro with their thumbs.  Their Marriages are sometimes celebrated with great pomp but generally they show more pomp at a funeral than joy at a wedding,  The funerals attendants and corps are always dressed in white.  Whlst the attendants to a wedding are dressed in the gayest colors scarlet pink & blue & yellow however none but the family of the Emperor or his relations or the relations of confutze are allowed to wear yellow for yellow is the imperial color.  A bride is always passed over a pan of charred coal at the door of the house or wedding room.   The lover and the young lady never see each other until the marriage and their parents always choose for them Some person who once advocated the doctrine of letting the young folks choose for themselves were hanged for their doctrines.   The English at Canton have been so much among the common folks that all or nearly all of the river people can understand english but they render it according to their own idiom which makes it quite laughable

for upstairs they always say top side.  for I can get they say mi can catchee.  for very large  Muchee largee  for business the call pidgion.  such as muchabobery pidgeon means a great deal of noise.  for I will walk with you to the Consuls and speak to him of the business they say Mi walkee he to Consul Mi speakee he of the pidgion.  for when will you ship sail  When he ship walkee &c.  Whilst we were in the River our sick list increased greatly many of the many were taken sick with a chill and were soon on their back and within 48 hours they were almost beyond hope many died of this malignant type and many more came near dying.   I was quite sick with it and was almost dispaired of but one day whilst I was thus low Capt. P. sent me down from Canton a letter from home and I think it helped me along very greatly indeed for the next day our good doctor came to me felt my pulse looked at my tongue and there was such a satisfactory smile came over his features that I was sure I was getting well but what was one of the greatest treats to me was that some ice came on board from an American vessel and as a present to the officers I got a good glass and a big one two and I felt it clear down to my toes,  several men died of this complaint viz. type among them was the Capt of our fore top and a bandsman  We buried them on the top of a hill near the reach.  Every day a pass boat goes up & down from Canton to Macoa and it is always full of passengers.  They have Mat sails and about every two feet is a long bamboo [?running?] tho the sail and to each end of this bamboo is a sheet

which leads aft. and each bamboo also has a [?panel?] around the mast the sail thus lays very flat against the mast or from it according to the manner of sailing.   the go about very quickly and the sail reefs from the bottom the rudder [crossed out:  leads from] unships and every boat has an eye painted on each bow for the Chinese say "No can see no can sabee" and thus they go  their anchors are made of very heavy wood with a stone to back it.  I have seen junks of about 1000 tons built after the same fashion   their hulls are nearly the shape of half of an egg cut longitudinally and some of them have three masts and always they have a number of swallowtailed flags with dragons painted or worked on them or long [?] streamers and ingenious [crossed out:  wind instruments]  weather vanes  They always unship their rudder when they come in port and these rudders are always pierced with more or less hole.   The stern is always painted a la China  viz with dragons and serpents and devils &c  The Chinese are very superstitious and every junk has a jos or idol when they have a head wind or bad weather they burn sandal wood and camphor all the time before the adorable jos.  And at sunrise and sunset the always burn a few leaves of gilt paper and stick up a taper or a match at one end of the boat.  The names of some of the Men are very singular to our ears.  they sound some of them very much like hang-high hang-low hang-you &c and then there is A-hem  ah-hem a-yoke a-yuke hum & Hom onh & unh  a-heap a-cut a-young  How-gna &c &c.

There are no horses used as beasts of burden but they carry every thing on their shoulders.  Heavy bales of silks and even guns they mannage [sic] to carry from one place to another without using horses.  Sedans or palanquins are carried by the natives on their shoulders.  the American and English ladies never venture out in any [crossed out: thing] other way than thus, for should they walk there is such a crowd of Men and boys gather around that they are not only unpleasantly situated but often grossly insulted,  they have in Canton a very excellant [sic] custom amongst the Merchants which is this when a visiter [sic] enters their store they close the doors and keep out all intruders or other Customers until  you are satisfied with their purchases.  The Chinese clerks are not tho quite as spry and active as our young clerks nor are they quite as agreeable for tho they attend to their duties with a certain sullenness of Manner that surprises an English-man or European,   the Chinese call their acts and plays sing songs 9crossed out:  because they] (Canton English) because their plays are kind of operas.  Some of their exebitions [sic] or plays are attended with such scenes as would not be allowed on an American or European stage.  Europeans usually carry out a play until the wedding when they are married and the world looses sight of them but a Chinese play proceeds usually to a greater extent sometimes even to the birth of a son [crossed out: sometimes].   The Chinese are great gamblers but I do not understand their games,  The boys seem never to play any games of amusement and the girls are but seldom seen,  in every family the parents always try to educate and raise one as a lady for this purpose they clap an iron or wooden shoe on the feet and

keep it there as long as possible.  these poor people are quite unfortunate for should they not get married or should their parents fail or die they have either to starve or turn harlots or kill themselves  this last is some times done the second nearly always and the first but seldom.   Chinese women are not proverbialy virtuous but if we believe the Chinese themselves they bear watching in a very strict manner and so do the Chinese husbands.  There are kinds of domestic slaves in China but how they are bound I do not know but I believe that the parent may sell his child when his others are in great distress [crossed out: ; The growth of China]  The Trees of China are so various that it is impossible for me who am not botanist to give any account of them suffice it to say that the trees called the pride of China grow here in great quantities and also in a beautiful and charming manner.   I did not visit the great silk factories but saw a few cookoons in a private establishment: they were attended by Men & Women boys & girls but I do not remember the Method.  A few hundred miles above Canton are large and high mountains which are inhabited by the Maetsou.  The Canton people contract with them for wood which these people cut down put in the river and mark according to orders the Chinese send a messenger up to pay for it either in goods or Money.  This they do all the time tho this province is nearly always at war and in rebellion against the Celestial brother of the sun & moon &c &c.  The Mandarines lay a tax every time they see fit on the rich Merchants to pay for something that never was nor never will be but always take care to line their own pockets with it  this the Chinese call in Canton English Squeezing for should the Merchants refuse to pay they do punish him either with a bamboo or by laying him on a board and putting others on his belly they lay

weights on it until he agrees to fork over the change.  The Chinese Commodore or Admiral during the late war with the English went to Admiral Elliott with a flag saying that it was very necessary for them to make a [?] as he expressed it. but said he suppose you no put plum pidgion in your gun me not put plum pidgeon in Mine,  After the war the English Admiral sent a few congrove rockets to the Chinese manderines as presents.  Now it is a property of these rockets that if they are not started properly they will turn and return amongst their employers so there was about 50 of them got together to let it off and unfortunately it turned back on them which caused a few deaths and a great fright.  they thought that the English Men did it on purpose.  The Paxan shell they called twice Eye shot because it first knocked a hole and then exploded.  They say when speaking of the war on Chinese Mandarine dam fool dam coward ran away first man &c but now china man sabee more of the gun pidgeon.  besides this they are copying the Make of all manner of European arms & discarding their own curious and clumsy things that are made more to look at than to use,  There is an inveterate hatred between the Malay & China races and sometimes there is a battle or sea fight between them that is well contested but generally 40 Malays will thrash 100 China Men.  In every street in {crossed out:  China]  Canton there are more or less jugglers who perform some very curious tricks.  One man whom I noticed had taut [sic] a bird to pick out a certain [?] card from about 100 or more all tuned edge ways to the bird.

another let a Number of lizards & snakes run down his throat (Apparantly so)  and many other curious tricks,  Some of the painting of the Chinese are truely beautiful and extremely well done, however their paintings generally fade after three or 4 years exposure to the air on account of the badness of their paints or the Mixture of them.  There are a peculiar kind of boats about Canton & Macoa which boats are called Tanka Boats they are usually pulled by women or rather sculled by them for they have only a stern oar except when they are going a long distance.  the tradition of these boats is as follows that a family once owned a boat which was round or rather oval like an Egg and that there was a great quarrell about the boat for want of room so one day they split it in two and thus made half eggs which they covered with mats and that this being a good model they had built their boats so ever since   it appears in the tradition that the quarrel of the family and that the spliting [sic] of the boat was a plan of the great and upright Fo in order to teach his favourite children the Chinese the Method of building good and substantial boats.  The Chinese make very beautiful and [?thick?] Matting it is made in Canton and of almost any figure or Shade.  The glass factories in Canton are quite extensive and they make quite good and cheap glasses.  they also make very excellent spectacles of Christals and of such large dimensions that an old China man looks like

he was nearly all eyes but at the same time it gives him or them a very venerable appearance which the Chinese pride them selves Much on viz the venerableness of their appearance and the length of their black tails.  The women do up their hair very similar to the old fashion of America viz something like an old fashion tea pot the hair done up on the back of heir head like a handle.  They do not appear to have a very high idea of the beauty of their gods for one day in making a gallant speech to one of the young ladies I compared her to the Celestial Chinese god to the great and big brass Fo of Canton when she flew in a great passion and ordered me to leave her presence.  One day I was lost in the crooked windings of the streets of Canton and I wandered around until it began to grow dark & darker and the thick crowd kept pressing me onward I did not know wherefore everyone appeared to be going the same way and two thirds of the people had lanterns.  So the best I could do was to keep along with the crowd which at length arrived at a sing-song the play was quite interesting to the audience it seemed for there was a continual laugh until the sceen [sic] was over.  the subject of the play appeared to be a love sceen .  I dare not describe it here for it would be unfit to read, of course I could understand nothing but the actions.  And any fool can tell a love sceen from a quareel [sic] tho the language was twice chinese

and that kind of tongue I think would puzzle the devil himself to talk or understand, fortunately I found a China man ho spoke English he told me how to find the London Hotel which I did without much trouble.  One day in Canton as I was walking around I came to the gate of the city  I was induced to go in no one said anything to me until I had gone a long ways up the Main Street but the folks looked very hard at me  I passed one or two large & tall pagodas and several fine house and one or two Chinese temples all of which I took a squint at.  After going along about ½ a mile or 3/4 the boys began crying out Fanginlow and some young men showed their dislike to my presence by pointing back to the gate and talking very furiously.  Finding times getting rather warm I walk back & went out of the gate without further trouble more than a few loud laughs and an occasional cry of Fan-gin-low.  The Chinese stories of the creation and deluge and of other things appear to be very singular they say there was once a man and woman created along time ago some million of years ago and that these people lived a very long & happy life in the interior of China, that afterwards there was a deluge agrees with out dates viz 4000 years ago.  They speak of each Emperor and his dinasty.  They speak of Barbarians visiting their country with red hair and blue eyes,  The also speak of the birth of Christ, One of the Chinese tales that was told me resembled very much some of the old German romances or fairey tales.  It was as follows as near as I can recollect.  A very good man went into the woods to cut a stick of wood,   Having cut it, a very old looking man walking passed asked  him to come along with him.  This he did and went to the top of a hill having placed his axe by his side they commenced a philosophical conversation

and having refreshed themselves and bid adieu he went to pick up his axe, and lo! the handle had rolled off and the axe was nearly eaten up with rust.  he thought it very strange but never-the-less he thought that he would go home, but when he got to his native town it was all in ruins he wondering went to the grave yard and even there he only found some very old and mouldering tomb-stones of his family name.  The story then goes on to tell how he proceeded and how the people wondered at his strange language and how the boys laughed at him and how the poor old fellow died or was taken to heaven to dwell amongst the philosophers   Mohometans are allowed in any part of China whilst Christians have been denied.  the Missionaries in China have written home very long accounts of how many converts they have made. but they tell stories, I do not believe that there is 2 Chinese Christians in the whole of China.  Those who attend church are only induced to do so by their allowance of rice and stop their rice they turn back to their old religion these people are called by the sea faring people rice Christinas but by the Missionaries they are called christians.  The Bogue or Bocca Tigris is as I have before remarked very well fortified but the fortifications are Chinese built and each one of them except those on the island are built under hills that overlook them,  Besides this the walls of the forts are nothing but a curtain without bastions or counter batteries and the guns can only point in one direction and do not protect each other,  The Chinese appear to be almost devoid of patriotism at least as regards the present dynasty; for during the english war the chinese for a trifle would assist the english to [?chay?] their guns up the hills  But still the Chinese never leave their country but what they still look forward to the time when they expect to return to their homes and to their parents,  I have often sat and looked at the chinese boats  and boatmen with their wives and children.  The Children almost entirely naked and lying fast asleep on the rounded roof of the boat where the least roll would send them into the river but there they lay sleeping as sound and as careless as if in a bed.   each little fellow with

a calabash lashed around his neck.  so that if the urchin should tumble overboard that he can be caught.  The Mother usually sits sewing, not with her fingers but with her thumb pushing the needle tho with a thimble on the end of her thumbs.  Every day whilst we were at Blenheim Reach we used to serve out the scraps of provisions that were left and you may suppose that it was a noisy and amusing scene, I have seen old women whom one would have thought could not have walked, jump over young ones heads and run scrambling from one boat to the other over the backs of the others and run dashing up to the ladder holding out a calabash for her allowance when a rain would come on I would frequently go to a port to watch their manoeuvers, no sooner than the rains begins to fall when such a pulling off clothes you never did see, each Man and Woman and child trying to get them off before they get wet.  All of said clothes are immediately crammed into a calabash and it turned upside down to keep the rain out, I have often thought how miserable some of these people must live, as their only house is a small boat.  scarcely large enough for one, However there are other boats which are larger and have mat roof and are comparitively speaking comfortable, whilst we lay in Blenheim Reach our sick list increased to about 80 most of them of billious or rather tipus fever.  Several men (3) died and I came within one of it  I remember distinctly one day the doctor came and felt my pulse, and then he smiled I knew then that I was better, and so after a long spell I at last got well but was extremely weak  This tipus fever comes on with a chill and head ache and one would think that is was nothing but chills and fever.  it is very fatal to foreigners after the sickness increased in such a manner we choped down to the Bogue where we laid about one month longer.  Whilst we were at the Bogue the french frigate cleopatra was

there with a french Commissioner.  One Night after the Conclusion of the treaty between the French and Chinese.  The french Man fired a salute lighted their ship up very brilliantly burnt blue lights and rockets &c. to which the Chinese forts answered.  It was a grand sight and the forts and Men of War junks did not get thro with their salutes till after mid night,  It was a very dark night and I fancied that some of these forts whilst firing resembled a volcano,  On the river was a large and brilliant procession of boats with thousands of lights. and Chinese fire works.  On the walls of the island fort were a large number of soldiers with torches.  All together it was a brilliant and grand affair. We dropped down to Macoa.  Our sick list getting smaller on the first of September having got all our provisions on board we sailed from Macoa.  At leaving Azoke & A-hem our compradors hoisted a long bamboo with about half a bushel of fire crackers on it and also an American flag,  As he shoved off they touched them off and there was much a [?] and cracking and it seem so laughable that I believe if the men had not been restrained they would have given him three cheers.  Out-side of Macoa harbour we saw several english Men of War and one steamer,  one day in a Merry tone I asked one of our Mess the following question.  Dave.  Can you find the latitude having given the three following parts. viz "our ship is home ward bound, the grog goes backward and it is bean soup day to day"   he answered it by the following lines the same evening which he has kindly dedicated to me, on the 12th of Sept we arrived in Manilla bay  it it is a large and commodious bay and is situated at the south west end of the island, it is surrounded by very high hills.  All of which have at some day been volcanic.  one

The Invocation
or
"The Great Problem Solved"
Dedicated to Mid'n W. P. Buckner U.S. Navy
by W. F. Davidson U.S. N
Invocation
Awake my harp, and muse divine
And let my thoughts like meteors shine
Let deep research and works of art
Assist me through my fearful part.
Give me great Euclid's learned head.
Let Newton's lustre around me shed
One bright halo to guide my steps
Through Calculation's unfathom'd depths.
- Spirit of Thales, assist me now
To twine fame's garland round my brow
And Pythagoras lend, lend thy hand
While at the threshold of fame I stand.
Oh, Plato! teach my mind to soar
To the path that leads to distinction's door.
- Shades of Archimedes I call on thee
To fly to my aid - also great Ptolemy -
And oh Galileo - thou man of glass
Let some of they wisdom to me pass
(Over)

Oh France with thy renowned Legendre
O'ere the field of science I strive to wander
"LaPlace" - "La Grange" - "[?Farvar?]" - "Bonny castle"
"Bourdon" - "Day" - "Pierce" with thee I'll wrestle
"Herschell" must guide me through the skies
To unfold rich wonders to my gaping eye's
"Simeon" and "Brewster" - "Hutton" and "Playfair"
Rise from they graves - or I must despair.
And sink to the dust in deep degradation
Or answer this question in plain Navigation -
Pity! Ye Gods the plight that I'm in
I strive fame's golden honors to win
I pray thee offer me one suggestion
I'll do my best upon the question -
Oh fly to my aid all men of learning
And heap the honors for which I'm burning.
"Bowditch" and "Maury" try thy powers
And gather for thy brows there flowers
That ne'er must wither, while time shall roll
Or the iceberg lasts at the Artic Pole.
"Davies" bend o'er thy Midnight lamp 
- - While weary sentries around thee tramp
(Over)

And guard West Point from 'hap or harm;
Rise Davies rise and work this charm.
Twill gain for thee everlasting fame
And enhance the value of thy name.
"Roche" arise, the list's are ope'd for thee
To make discoveries on this science sea
Come, launch thy bark - push boldly on
Use perseverance and the goal is won
"The Problem Solved
Ye Men of Science - Ah! how d'ye do?
By the way the questions here for you
'Tis this "Bean Soup our ration was today"
"The Ship sails on her homeward way"
"The Grog went backwards to the crew"
Thus I bring the subject full in view 
With these three given you'll try to find
"Our Latitude and Time combined"
And since you know what is the question
I'll offer only one sugestion
Multiply Dunderfunk by Salthorse
You'll have Bread Puddings - (Minus) Sauce
Reduce Molasses to the most common Swankey

You'll have your first term - A Pork Eating Yankee
With these two terms - now in the rough
You'll add one lb of Rasin Duff
Then take the figure - "Pons Asinorem
Go to the Master - For "Line Sights" bore him
If he's unwell, or somewhat fat-i-gu-ed
He'll give you the Time  - Likewise the Latitude
To atoms - by the Devil - may I be jerked
Tis the only way the Problem can be worked.
"Dedication"
The Problem's solved - I'm quite elated
My Poem to thee is dedicated.
And Buck" old boy in humor merry
I've done my best.  upon this query
So if I've pleas'd you - keep it Buckie" 
With the kind regards of a Chinese Fuhhie
Fuhhie pronounce Fuckie Means friend or countryman.

the scenery around Manilla is very beautiful the Hills being very high and covered with verdure.  And the vallies either filled with thick forests or cultivated field, there are several islands in the bay of Manilla, all of which have a few inhabitants.  The City of Manilla is built on a level plain and at a short distance its numerous forts and domes and spires give it a beautiful and imposing appearance, besides this the City is divided into two parts one called the Spanish town and the other the Native town.  the Native town is nearly twice as large as the White but the White city is very strongly fortified and walled it is as strong a place as I have seen for a long time  a ditch surrounds the whole place about 30 feet wide and full of water.  on the most assailable point there are three walls and two ditches with drawbridges & the whole city of Manilla may be said to be built amongst churches for near every 10th house is a church.  and such churches as are seldom seen viz large Massive buildings with high towering steeples and deep toned bells and the whole interior is decorated with images & painting of our Saviour which pious fathers and sisters have from time to time presented to the church, some of these paintings I have heard were very old and so they looked and some of them were remarkably well executed.  The altars are usually nearby and in many instances are gorgeously decorated with gilt or gold ornaments, these set off by numerous lights which are kept continually burning, besides which as it was a feast day or rather a Collection of feasts and the alters were decorated with branches of orange and other trees, which gave the whole church an air of quietness and innocence that would [crossed out: have been] be difficult to describe.   The Choirs of these churches are usually very good even excellent, one day whilst passing near the factories I heard a remarkably sweet strain of music proceeding from a church when I entered it I observed all persons on their knees and some few looked hard at me, so as I thought it would rude to go out without showing at least a proper respect and that I had so far only shown a rude curiosity which would be almost inexcusable

so without more ado down I knelt between two girls, and of course they made room for me, when I out-watch bill and commenced saying my pater noster with as good a grace as I well knew how.  by and by I began to get very tired of kneeling there as the pavement was very hard, and I observed that all of the girls had so rolled up their dresses that they made a sort of cushions, and again I observed that I was nearly the only male in the house that the whole church was full of females and only one or two males.  by and by several ladies & girls rose up near me and started out I followed. glad to be released from the painful position of kneeling.  they stoped at the Holy found and sprinkled their faces, crossing themselves.  I did the same, when I heard an old lady say, bueno Catolico! and another, bien Christiano!  Once out of the church I was not in a hurry to go back but was looking which way I should go and wondering where all these women came from, going idly along I happened to take the same direction with those girls between whom I was kneeling and on passing them one or two called out, hist! hist! and asked me if I was an Americano. or engleise on answering they asked me to go to their house which I did. and was well treated, and requested to call again which I did several times during our stay.  They always received me kindly and the girls were so interesting and pretty that tho I could only half understand them, I became quite smitten and when I left Manilla it was with a sigh.  There is  river which runs thro the city of Manilla and is about 200 yards wide it has a very rapid current and each side of the river is built up with stone so that a vessel may lay close up to the wharf almost any where along its banks.

The following song written of Cape Horn by one of our reefers.  And sung by him on an occasion of splicing the fore & main braces in the steerage  Met with great applause  from the admiring & half tight mids
Half a Pint of Kisah
Draw up my boys and form a ring
Ang gives us the song of ring ching ching.
We'll wash it down with a good gin Sling.
or a half a pint of Kisah
Sing RingaChing ching ching ching ching ching &c.
or a half a pint of Kisah
And as we sing this glorious song
With chorus loud and rum punch strong
We;ll call on all to pass a-long
A half a pint of Kisah  &c.
Our ship has sail'd the word quite round
And now have lads we're homeward bound
A happier set there'll ne'er be found
with a half a pint of Kisah.
And Ive have crossed over many a sea
With boundley thoughts and souls as free 
Especially when we are on a spree
over a half a pint of Kisah.
Well here's the ladies health my boys,
The partners of our griefs and joys
Their sweet smiles our gloom destroys 
Like a half a pint of Kisah

Hold on we're about to part I think,
We might as well take a parting drink
While each man his thought must sink
In a half a pint of Kisah.
Come now we'll close our jolly lay
And betake our selves to bed away.
Yet much I would prefer to stay
over a half a pint of Kisah.

The Glorious Quarterdeck

for fun and glee.
And a Reefers life select.
We laugh and talk 
While the Watch we walk
On the Glorious Quarter deck.
Some hate its name
Some seek its fame.
And its honors all expet.
While some like best
the old arm chest 
On the glorious quarter deck.
When on the deep 
Some hide and sleep
(By law they risk their neck.)
But what care they
so they seep away
Their watch on the Quarter deck.

one thing we hate
but to our fate
to be at the call and beck.
of those who gide on the weather side
of the glorious quarter deck.

With great delight.
While ore the sea we float,
we pass the joke
we laugh and smoke.
In the starb'bridle port.

times to Come.
And of girls that we shall court.
And each can tell [crossed out:  of loves]
of loves deep  spell
in the starb' bridle port.

do everything in the starb' bridle port

To Washington P. Bucknel
My old watch-mate, shall the nights
You and I once talked together
Be forgot like common things
Like some dreary night that brings
Nought save foul weather?
We were gay when you and I
Talked of golden things together
Of Love and Rhyme and Books and Men
Ah! our hearts were joyous then
As the wild birds feather;
Yes those times are fled I Know
Along with care and changing weather
But hath thy heart no backward flights
That we again may see the nights
And smile together
When the soul doth foward bend
And dream the sweet world hath no end
Neither spot, nor shade nor showers
Must ne'er erode those happy hours
We've passed together, my bosom friend.
Jno. E. H.

First night out of the "Homeward Bound"
Soon noble "Cristons" bold and towering height
Was lost amid the darkening gloom of night
The low and scowling clouds came hovering round
The bounding bark - the "Homeward bound"
Fast, fast flew she before the fresh'ning blast
High from her bows the whitened foam she cast
And plunging through the swelling fire tipp'd main
As though to rest upon its bosom she disdain'd
Happy's the freight the gallant ship now bears 
For Joy and Hope with each glad heart has shares
Of coming times - of home - a pleasing tale
Glanced thro' the gloom and whispers in the gale
Onward the ship in triumph cleaves the tide
Gracefuly she rolls and laves her warlike side
Swift as the playful dolphin, that by her swims
And light as the scar'd [?roc?] she o'er the surface skims
Thoughtfully the watchful Reefer leand upon the rail
His pretty sail boat - the lake - the quiet wooded dale
Come to his mind; above them all the fairy form
Of one that's ne'er forgot in calm or storm

This night recalls to him the days of yore
That they together spent in rambling o'er
The hills, and dales 'mid flowers that smile
Discounting of all thats beautiful the while
On fancys ear still breathes the sound
Time shall ne'er loose the spell affection bound
The wind-god now was gathering all  his wrath
And swept the lowering clouds before his path 
With fearful crash, down came the gust
Lit by a livid flash, and o'er the vessel burst
Reeling and labouring, madly on to dash
She starts like a mettled steed that fear'd the lash
Far away astern an undulating flame
Tells through the dismal dark the course she came.
The fierce stern god of storms has passed
The noisy surges lowly now is cast
Like some fond friend with loving tender sight
The gentle moon beamed forth her silver light
And stars stole out like fancies fair 
That comes in the light of the Sailors prayer
Again the anxious Reefer scans the sky
On one bright star at last is fixed his eye

Oh what tomes of pure and holy thought
Upon that sad gazers mind is wrought
A flood of happiness he fancies lays in store
In that dear home upon the distant shore
Jno. E Hart
"The Erring"
Think gently of the erring
Ye know not of the power
With which the dark temptation came
In some unguarded hour
Ye may not know how earnestly 
They struggled, or how well
Until the hour of weakness came
And sadly there they fell"
"Think gently of the erring
Oh! do not thou forget
However darkly stained by sin
He is thy brother yet

Heir of the self-same heritage
Child of the self-same God
He hath but stumbled in the path
Thou hast in weakness trod"
"Speak gently to the erring 
For is it not enough
That innocence and peace is gone
Without thy censure rough
It sure must be a weary lot
That sin-crushed heart to bear
And they who share a happier fate
Their chidings well may spare"
"Speak gently to the erring
Thou yet mays't lead them back
With holy words and tones of love
From Misery's thorny track
Forget not thou hast often sinned
And sinful yet must be
Deal gently with the Erring one
As God has dealt with thee"
Jno. E. Hart

with two or three men who were in the 25th of May they told me that a proof charge of powder had been put into the guns two wound shot and a stand of grape or musket balls our spare deck was found full of musket balls I asked them how that was they said that these balls were from 6 lb swivels in the tops,  The Don Pedro sailed again fell in with and captured the 25th of May after an action of 5 or 6 hours in which all her masts were shot away and nearly all  her guns dismounted and 4/5 of her crew killed or wounded.  The Capt was wounded lost both legs when he got into Rio he was taken the best of care of treated with every attention  A parole offered him balls and parties given to the no legged hero the Emperor gave him the cross of honor and the Empress confered the star of he Martial Saint of Portugal,

the word was pass beat to quarters but she was alongside of us our guns nearly touching, I distinctly heared the order to break stop stand by fire.  She was a 24 gun sloop of war 32 pounders.  I never thought that 12 guns could do so much execution 3 of our [?] were knocked into one  the nettings all knocked in the main and spar deck ripped up so that they gave way and the guns of the spar and gun deck by their weight fell thro this started the [?] deck besides there was a shot between wind and water and starting the beems of the [?] deck caused her to leak terrably.  There was a cry of Terror thro the ship the Main [?] tree was shot away and the flapping of the sail with the confusion on deck and the fright of the man at the wheel put her up in the wind and flat aback.  in less time than I have taken to tell it the 25th of May luffed under our stern [?] sharp up and gave us he same broadside a raking fire but tho this did us a great deal of damage it killed fewer men than the first fire for all the [?cholows?] ran down into the hold & cockpit and no one was to be seen at their quarters but the officers and the few Americans French English and dutch who were on board.  many of the cholous were run thro by their officers or shot down by them for their base cowardice.  as we were so superior to the 25 of May in every thing they concluded best to haul off tho had they given us another broadside we would have been obliged to surrender, so she hauled close on a wind.  She had not got more than a mile before our Mizzen Mast went ripping up the spar deck in its fall.  then she wove and stood for us but we even as damaged as we were could sail 2 miles to her one and soon distanced her the report of the officers when we got into Rio was 50 killed & 15 wounded altogather, we had to go watch and watch to the pumps and once during a squall tho we heeled over but little I thought we would founder as the water poured in in 20 holes,  we got safe into Rio our Capt was broken and dismissed and several of the crew shot for cowardice  she was 6 months there before she was again ready for sea.  I had written to the American Commodore an account of our impressment  he demanded us we were shoved into a dungeon where the mud was over our shoes fed on jerk beef & water until we were finally delivered up and sent home.  I afterwards sailed

it tho it was blown away in 15 minutes.  As soon as she was before it she righted and scuded along before it at the rate of 12 knots it had blowed so hard that the sea could not rise into waves but was lifted up in spray so much so that whilst on the fore yard I was dripping wet with salt water.  it was difficult to hold on aloft.  at last it moderated and the sea began to rise  we set a new main topsail to steady her. but two of her main deck guns got adrift there were a lot of fellows asleep just to leeward of them and when they broke loose they rolled on to them it was horrible to hear the cries of the crushed men who were not killed  some cursing themselves their country their saints and their God.  now you know sir that cholows dont sleep in hammochs so we had no means to Chock them except with a few Hammocks that belonged to the Englishmen and Americans.  soon the gun deck was deserted and at every roll of the ship these guns threatened to knock the sides out of her we could feel her quiver to her bows  No one dare venture below there was the guns adrift dashing in bulkheads down stancheons and out ports and threatening to beat the sides out of her already the sea was pouring the gun deck ports and the birth deck was all afloat and if some thing was not done we would most certainly go down or be knocked to pieces by our own guns.  The Capt who was a brave man called a few men and officers around them all volunteers each took a hammock a billet of wood or coil of rope you could only use one hand for the ship rolled so one hand had to clasp the Coil line which was rove fore and aft on all decks.  after great exertions they were at last secured the Carpenter [?] in new ports but it was sad to think of what it cost us our Capt had both legs crushed off above the knees and three or four Americans or Englishmen had been jammed to death against the side of the ship the command then fell on a Portuguese the gale abated we had fine weather bent new sails and repaired our damages run out the guns at their proper places, one morning just as the drum beat off it was hardly daylight it was the start watch on deck and I was stationed at the main tack.  we were on the last tack and the only place we had any nettings was the gangway as the cholous all sleep on sheep skins  a small vessel was seen ahead we were going about 4 knots.  She had no colors flying and was standing down for us.  all of our men had clustered in the lee gangway to stow their sheep skins and on the gun deck every body was looking out of the ports.  She ranged up so close to us that we luffed to keep our main yard from catching her as soon as she got ahead she rounded up {?Buenos ayrean?] colors

in Armament.  And every thing else we ran down the coast on the larb' tack until we got into the Horse latitudes.  here we were becalmed for several days.  on this part of the coast men of war are seldom ever seen the generally keep further to seaward whilst the coasting craft run close in.  one evening a light [?breeze?] sprung up the Capt who was a jolly old [?] determined to have a little frolic ashore so we ran into a small bay came too with the kedge and [crossed out:  got out a few] [?] a few boats.  All the officers except those who were wanted on duty went  I belonged to the gig and of course went too.  I never in all my life saw a more pleasant time, the spanish girls in this lat 32º were as fair as our own and so kind and modest and not so modest either we staid on shore 3 days enjoying ourselves and I was known as the tall American courted almost by all the girls and associating with the same company as the Capt who supplied me with Money, I never was so sorry so sorry to leave a place in My life and when we did we each got a sly Kiss and saw a starting tear from our favourites.  one morning a signal was made from the ship the Capt instantly called us all together we took our leave with sad hearts and repaired on board, the amount was that a coaster had reported that she had been chased by the 25th of My 2 days before.  we made sail with a very light wind and had just cleared the [crossed out:  Harbour] Bay when it fell [?] there were a few white fleecy looking clouds almost in the zenith.  they seemed almost to drop down to our trucks  we now commenced preparing for a gale.  sent down our top gallant masts and yards and rigged in flying jib boom, furled all but the close reefed main topsail and fore storm stay sail soon we could not see a cloud except to the W and there was a thin-bow [?apparent?] no more than a yard wide extending from horizon to Horizon the centre of the bow being about 45º elevation.  it was not long in coming and when it struck us our sails which were set were blown loose almost on her beem ends.  If it had not been for the English and American seamen on board she would have gone down as she was laying broadside to the wind and the cholous were calling on St. Mary & Maria & Joseph and a Whole lot of other damed humbugs in place of hauling on ropes as they should have done like men.  The capt cursed and swore hard enough to turn the sky yellow and broke his speaking trumpet and spy glass over their heads to make them take hold of the ropes.  the Americans and english alone ran forward and loosed and set the foresail this put her

the following story was told me one evening during the first watch by a man in whom the officers and men had great confidence and who had no doubt been in better business than Qr Master
I shipped in Baltimore and came to Rio with a load of flour and other American produce  I was then a younker about 19 and was making my third voyage.  there was several of us on board who were of the same age  one morning we took the boat to go to Market pulled ashore landed the boys and as it was a damp drizzly morning we left only two keepers in the boat and stepped up to get a glass of grog when I came on shore I felt as if some thing would happen the day was dark damp and dreary such a day as one feels his spirits sink and has to splice the main Brace.  However I got a good lignumvitae stick and swore if the Cholow press gang came about Me I would give them the hardest end.  I was then as I have said 19 or 20  I was as stout as an ox and my young blood almost piped thro my veins {crossed out words].  I had scarcely emptied my glass and turned round to go down and relieve the others in the boat to allow them to come up and freshen the nip (there was 6 of us) when we were attacked by the Brazilian press gang there was about 20 of them and I tell you what we made them stand for it for our sticks and jack knives were severe tho not dangerous weapons.  however after a hearty beating we were obliged to knock under and all of us boat keepers and all were put on board of the Don Pedro 64 [?] frigate, where we were forced to sign articles and in about 3 weeks we left on a cruise.  She was a fine ship her battery was of the best and all 32s  She was a fast sailer and was officered by english officers with a few Spanish senors.  We had a crew of 650 men mostly cholows  All the petty officers were either English or American, Brazil and Buenos Ayres were then at war there were many Baltimore privateers and men of war in her service.  some of these ships held my old ship mates.  there was one had done a great deal of damage to the Brazilian Commerce the Don Pedro had orders to hunt for her and take her.  Now the 25th of May was a dull sailer.  We could beat her under topsails so the order were to find her for if found she must certainly be taken.  We were not very prudent about going to quarters as we were so superior to her
